urn:contentItem:6GSC-N1X3-RS4W-50W2-00000-00September 18, 2025: Autonomous University of Barcelona Horses, possible allies in forest fire prevention2025-09-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSSeptember 18, 2025: Autonomous University of Barcelona Horses, possible allies in forest fire prevention

The research-which included the participation of Boumort Wildland, the Miranda Foundation, the Forest Horses association, and the University of Barcelona (UB)-reveals that horses adapt their diet according to breed, environment and use. This flexibility helps them play a complementary role alongside other herbivores in sustainable fire prevention strategies, given that their grazing reduces fuel loads and maintains open landscapes. The study was co-authored by researchers from the Department of Animal and Food Science at the UAB Jordi Bartolome and Araceli Gort-Esteve.

"Until now research on extensive herding and forest fire prevention has focused mainly on sheep and goats, with some isolated studies done on breeds of rustic cattle. There have been very few studies on horses within this context, since traditionally they are classified as plant grazers that have little effect on woody vegetations", explains Ariadna Nieto-Espinet, Ramon y Cajal researcher at the UdL and zooarchaeologist. "Our work is one of the first to use empirical data to analyse their potential in forest management in the Mediterannean", she adds.

urn:contentItem:6GSP-9MS3-RTDK-W31D-00000-00September 18, 2025: Study Highlights Role of Autonomous University of Barcelona Horses in Forest Fire Management2025-09-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSSeptember 18, 2025: Study Highlights Role of Autonomous University of Barcelona Horses in Forest Fire Management

Research conducted with the involvement of Boumort Wildland, the Miranda Foundation, the Forest Horses association, and the University of Barcelona (UB) indicates that horses modify their diets according to their breed, environment, and purpose. This dietary flexibility allows them to serve as valuable partners to other herbivores in sustainable strategies for fire prevention, as their grazing activity helps lower fuel loads and maintain open landscapes. The study was co-authored by Jordi Bartolome and Araceli Gort-Esteve from the Department of Animal and Food Science at the UAB. "Until now research on extensive herding and forest fire prevention has focused mainly on sheep and goats, with some isolated studies done on breeds of rustic cattle. There have been very few studies on horses within this context, since traditionally they are classified as plant grazers that have little effect on woody vegetation," states Ariadna Nieto-Espinet, a Ramon y Cajal researcher at the UdL and zooarchaeologist. "Our work is one of the first to use empirical data to analyse their potential in forest management in the Mediterranean," she further notes.

urn:contentItem:6H1V-8MF3-S53W-C3T5-00000-00New recruits bolster firefighting resources across Victoria: FFMVic2025-10-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisNew recruits bolster firefighting resources across Victoria: FFMVic

Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic), Media Release, 23 October 2025

Forest Fire Management Victoria’s (FFMVic) newest recruits are gearing up for the summer bushfire season, undertaking intensive training camps across the state.

The training camps ensure seasonal forest and fire operations officers are well-prepared to respond to emergencies and carry out vital work to reduce bushfire risk.

Photo: FFMVic

This summer, FFMVic is welcoming 636 seasonal firefighters who will work alongside our experienced permanent crews to help protect communities and the environment. Fourteen training camps are being held across the state over the coming weeks.

Photo: FFMVic

Recruits complete two weeks of classroom and field-based learning, covering topics such as fire behaviour, safety and survival techniques, fire suppression, working around aircraft, and planned burning.

The camps offer hands-on experience, including operating water pumps and chainsaws, and driving specialised firefighting vehicles.

Beyond emergency response, seasonal forest and fire operations officers also carry out important land management tasks such as mulching, mowing, slashing, and spraying.

They help maintain fuel breaks, public land roads, trails, recreation sites, and assist with planned burns.

This summer, 92 seasonal firefighters will be based in the Loddon Mallee Region, working from depots across the region.

Last year, FFMVic firefighters responded to more than 1,265 bushfires across Victoria and delivered priority planned burns to help reduce the impact of future fires.

Quotes attributable to Forest Fire Management Victoria Chief Fire Officer, Chris Hardman:

“Our seasonal forest and fire operations officers join us from diverse backgrounds, reflecting the communities we serve.”

“They play a critical role alongside our experienced crews, responding to bushfires in some of the state’s most remote and challenging environments to keep communities safe.”

“This summer, they’ll be part of a team of nearly 1800 frontline personnel and 1200 accredited incident management staff.”

Photo: FFMVic

Quotes attributable to Forest Fire Management Victoria Acting Deputy Chief Fire Officer – Loddon Mallee, Aaron Gay 

“With an increased risk of bushfires forecast for the region, our seasonal firefighters are an important and valued addition to our firefighting resources this summer.”

"New recruits train and work alongside our permanent firefighting crews, responding to bushfires rapidly to keep communities safe this summer.”

“Last year, Forest Fire Management Victoria responded to 233 bushfires in the Loddon Mallee region, also delivering priority planned burns which will help reduce the impact of bushfires this summer.”

Photo: FFMVicPhoto: FFMVicPhoto: FFMVic

urn:contentItem:6H4K-GV73-RV9M-74JT-00000-00Firing up ahead of challenging season2025-11-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisFiring up ahead of challenging seasonMichelle Smith

Inside the new funding to protect communities from bushfire risk.

A fleet of water tankers and new water storage facilities will be used to help fight bushfires across what is expected to be a challenging summer.

With dams and water storage levels lower than in previous years heading into summer, emergency authorities had feared that access to water for the state's aerial firefighting fleet and fire crews on the ground could be limited in some areas.

So mobile water tankers will be dispatched to firegrounds along with fire trucks and aircraft to ensure ample access to water, and a network of other water storage facilities, including large tanks, has been established.

CFA Chief Fire Officer Jason Heffernan confirmed that tankers would be used in the Ballarat region where needed.

The $10 million boost to ensure water access is part of $80 million of extra funding the state government has provided for the summer bushfire season.

The extra funding includes an extension to the aerial firefighting contracts, which saw 15 aircraft, including the Black Hawk firefighting helicopter based at Ballarat, come online more than a month early because of the fire threat. In addition, more than 130 extra Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) project firefighters have been employed for the bushfire season, and other measures have received extra cash to ensure community readiness for the summer.

"We know we've seen 20 months of underlying dryness across Victoria, and we've seen that in terms of our water storages and also local dams as well," Victoria's Emergency Services Commissioner Tim Wiebusch said.

"In addition to the aircraft that are now online and operating, we're also seeing CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria preparing strategic water locations across the state. Large tanks are being put into strategic locations and mobile tanks that will be filled by bulk water carriers over the fire season to make sure that the turnaround times for our fire appliances and our aviation fleet can be reduced, whilst not also drawing as much from local farm dams that we know are at very low levels at the moment."

Mr Wiebusch said rainfall over the past week might slightly delay fire risk in some parts of the state, but it would likely be an above-average fire season compared to recent years.

" The recent rainfall , whilst it might delay perhaps the onset of the fire risk in some parts of the state ... we're thinking about the extra growth that's going to come about because of that additional rainfall," he said.

"The Bureau is forecasting above-average temperatures for December, January and February, and so that means things will dry out again very much, and so that fire risk will return and because of that underlying dryness in our soils, that risk is already there."

If the fire season does extend past March, when the aerial firefighting contracts typically end, there are arrangements in place and funding to extend them.

Premier Jacinta Allan visited Ballarat Airport with Emergency Services Minister Vicki Ward, Environment Minister Steve Dimopoulos, and the heads of Victoria's emergency services agencies to announce the funding increase and urge landowners to prepare for the summer season.

"As we head into what is predicted to be another elevated and difficult fire season, we are all here today to talk about that fire preparedness, and also to encourage Victorians to play their part in getting ready for this coming fire season," the Premier said.

"We're acting early to protect communities across Victoria by ensuring our firefighters have the resources they need to keep Victorians safe."

The 133 new FFMVic firefighters, including 39 who will work across the Grampians region, have been training with fellow recruits at Creswick, learning the skills to fight fires and help keep communities and themselves safe.

They will be among 636 new seasonal firefighters joining FFMVic's permanent crews across the summer.

Recruits complete four weeks of classroom and field-based learning, covering topics such as fire behaviour, safety and survival techniques, fire suppression and working around aircraft.

"With an increased risk of bushfires forecast for the region, our seasonal firefighters are an important and valued addition to our firefighting resources this summer," FFMVic Grampians acting deputy chief fire officer Michael Condon said.

"New recruits train and work alongside our permanent firefighting crews, responding to bushfires rapidly to keep communities safe this summer.

"Last year, Forest Fire Management Victoria responded to over 100 bushfires in the Grampians region, also delivering priority planned burns which will help reduce the impact of bushfires this summer."

urn:contentItem:6H54-YYM3-RS8X-74S4-00000-00Race to fix trucks as fire season looms2025-11-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisTHENATIONPg. 3Race to fix trucks as fire season loomsJOHN FERGUSON, ASSOCIATE EDITOR, EXCLUSIVE

Victoria's forest fire chiefs are scrambling to get their full truck fleet back into service after finding potentially catastrophic cracks in the chassis of some -vehicles.

Workers are expecting some of the vehicles to be written off after cracks was found during checks last month. Forest Fire Management Victoria's fuel-reduction program has been complicated by the crisis.

The Allan government said that many vehicles had been cleared to go back into service, but the Australian Workers Union said it was expected that some would be written off because of the extent of the damage to the 290 Mercedes-Benz G-Wagons and 59 Unimogs.

The government did not say how many of the vehicles were back in operation, amid years of scandal in its fire services that has raised questions about the state's ability to prepare for bushfires and conduct a full-scale operation in the event of a Black Saturday-style disaster.

AWU Victorian president Ross Kenna said the government had initially described the problem as a minor issue, but once checks were conducted it was found to be widespread. "We know they are doing a fair bit of work now," he said.

Victoria's forest fire chiefs are scrambling to get their full truck fleet back into service after finding potentially catastrophic cracks in the chassis of some ­vehicles.

Workers are expecting some of the vehicles to be written off after cracks was found during checks last month.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's fuel-reduction program has been complicated by the crisis.

The Allan government said that many vehicles had been cleared to go back into service, but the Australian Workers Union said it was expected that some would be written off because of the extent of the damage to the 290 Mercedes-Benz G-Wagons and 59 Unimogs.

The government did not say how many of the vehicles were back in operation, amid years of scandal in its fire services that has raised questions about the state's ability to prepare for bushfires and conduct a full-scale operation in the event of a Black Saturday-style disaster.

AWU Victorian president Ross Kenna said the government had initially described the problem as a minor issue, but once checks were conducted it was found to be widespread.

"We know they are doing a fair bit of work now,'' he said.

There is speculation that some trucks will have to be written off as southeastern Australia faces a ­potentially serious fire season.

Mr Kenna said there had been cracking in different places in the chassis of both models of vehicles, which are central to fuel-reduction burning and other programs.

The Australian revealed this week that thousands of hectares of land across a broad area hit by the Ash Wednesday disaster remain unburnt in Victoria's Otway ­Ranges, as the window for planned controlled burns narrows ahead of summer.

Allan government figures showed fire agencies were making slow progress this year in the drive to implement planned burns and other fuel-reduction measures in an area ripe for a major disaster and which includes one of Australia's busiest summer tourist ­regions.

Mr Kenna said the last thing firefighters needed when facing a blaze was for a vehicle to break down.

The government said other vehicles had been brought in from outside the FFMVic fleet to help deal with the crisis.

"The safety of our firefighters is paramount. That's why regular safety inspections of vehicles and equipment are so important,'' a government spokesman said.

"FFMV has brought online ­additional vehicles to continue undertaking critical bushfire-­season preparations and respond to bushfire emergencies.''

Opposition land management spokeswoman Melina Bath said there were serious issues with the fuel-reduction strategy.

"Victoria is heading into one of its most dangerous fire seasons, yet Labor has pulled nearly 350 firefighting vehicles from service, a staggering blow to frontline preparedness," she said. "This isn't just mismanagement, it's a systemic failure, with FFMVic's shrinking fleet and Labor's stalled fuel-reduction program leaving regional Victorians dangerously exposed.

"Labor's failure to meet fuel-­reduction targets is compounded by a depleted FFMVic fleet, with hundreds of G-Wagons and Unimogs off the road. Communities are unacceptably left exposed."

The Howitt Society has warned that the halving of fuel-reduction measures in Victoria and since Labor was elected in 2014 has set the scene for disasters that could match or exceed this year's Los Angeles fires, when about 30 people died and more than 17,000 homes and buildings were razed.

The government was asked how many of the FFMVic trucks were back on the road, but did not provide an answer. The government also did not say whether the fleet problems had affected the fuel-reduction strategy but said the community was well protected due to a multi-agency approach.

urn:contentItem:6H6D-T293-RSJ3-81J6-00000-00Rainfall impacts planned burns2025-11-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 18Rainfall impacts planned burnsRemy Varga

Rainfall has ironically put Australia in danger of being woefully underprepared for the bushfire season, figures reveal.

In South Australia, the Department of Environment and Water has completed 13 of 47, about 28 per cent, of planned burns as part of the state's spring land-clearing program.

The department has rescheduled some planned burns due to recent rainfall and exceeded the burns target for autumn, completing 42 against a target of 37.

"Burns that are unable to be completed due to unsuitable weather are rolled over to the following spring or autumn as part of an ongoing, rolling three-year mitigation program," it said.

NSW has completed about 11 per cent of planned hazard-reduction burns ahead of summer as states and territories prepare for the looming bushfire season.

Queensland, Western Australia, Tasmania and the NT do not set hazard control or planned burning targets while the ACT and Victoria measure targets on risk instead of hectares.

The NSW Rural Fire Service has cleared 40,000ha of land since July 1, from a target of 370,000ha, and is aiming to clear a backlog accumulated over recent years due to wet weather and flooding.

"The most significant determining factor for the completion of hazard reduction work is the weather, with persistent rain across broad areas greatly hampering efforts in recent years," the RFS said.

Bureau of Meteorology senior climatologist Hugh Mc-Dowell said the coming summer would likely be warmer than average across Australia while the east could experience higher than average rainfall.

"Warmer than average is very likely," he said.

"Wetter than average is likely for parts of the east. Not everywhere is going to be wetter than average and it's not going to be wet all the time." Forest Fire Management Victoria has cleared 109,000ha. In Queensland, the Rural Fire Service has issued 21,000 permits for hazard reduction burning on private properties, slightly higher than average.

urn:contentItem:6GV3-DWK3-RV39-204H-00000-00SOC:Home sweet home: Ange hopes Forest fire in backyard2025-09-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisSPORTS NEWSSOC:Home sweet home: Ange hopes Forest fire in backyardLONDON Sept 26

  Ange Postecoglou has traipsed over 6000km with his new team, zooming around England, into Wales and over the seas to Spain while still seeking that elusive first win as Nottingham Forest boss.
   But on Saturday (Sunday AEST), he'll at long last be able to introduce himself to the Forest faithful at their City Ground citadel in Nottingham, and though he's not making a song and dance about his belated bow, he'll be quietly desperate for "home comforts" to finally help him break his duck at the fifth attempt.


   After an opening defeat at Arsenal in the Premier League and getting knocked out of the League Cup across the Welsh border in Swansea, he's since endured a draw at Burnley and, earlier this week, another with Real Betis on Forest's return to European competition after a three-decade absence.
   In the last three games, Forest have been leading, only to get pegged back, including a frustrating 85th equaliser that denied them in Seville on Wednesday.
   The 60-year-old Australian has shrugged off those near-misses so far, suggesting he's happy with the progress the side have made since he came on board as they've started to display all the attacking hallmarks of a Postecoglou side.
   But there can be no argument he could do with a win - quick - with Forest in 15th place, and achieving that in front of their fans against newly promoted Sunderland feels like an important staging post.
   "Playing away in football is always a challenging experience because it's the job of opposition supporters to make it as uncomfortable as possible for the visiting team. To have some home comforts tomorrow, from the people who support this football club and get behind the players, it's going to be great," said Postecoglou.
   "When the players walk out and they hear the noise that will be supportive of them, I think it will help the performance.
   "I am sure the fans are excited to see the team so irrespective of form or anything else, there should be a really good buzz at the stadium.
   "It's important, not necessarily for me but what we're trying to embark on. There's two ways to win faith. To win games, that's the instant one, but if you are not doing that there needs to be something that looks like it's encouraging.
   "And I get that people are putting it that I need to win my first game for whatever reason, but we need to win to make sure we're in a great position when everything clicks to make an impact.
   "Since the Arsenal game - at Swansea, Burnley and on Wednesday night - some of the football we played was really compelling because it's what we're working on.
   "The players - Igor [Jesus], Elliot [Anderson] - are growing all the time. The centre-backs are showing personality, the full-backs are adjusting."
   But Forest will be without midfielder Douglas Luiz, who faces a scan on the hamstring injury suffered against Betis, while centre-back Murillo remains absent with a thigh injury as they seek to beat a Sunderland side who are three points ahead of them in the table in seventh.

urn:contentItem:6H0J-2CW3-RSC3-923W-00000-00Trucks off the road ahead of summer sizzle2025-10-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisNews6Trucks off the road ahead of summer sizzleChelsea Wilson

'Our crown land firefighting fleet has been significantly impacted.'

Forest Fire Management Victoria has removed hundreds of Mercedes-Benz firefighting vehicles from service due to safety concerns.

After routine inspections revealed issues with the vehicles, 280 G-wagons and 59 Unimogs have been taken off the road to be checked and repaired if necessary.

"These repairs are being fast-tracked over the next two months," a Victorian government spokesperson said.

"FFMVic is working on agreements to secure additional emergency response vehicles from other states if required."

The vehicles are used by FFMVic for accessing remote terrain and have been grounded because of cracking issues with the chassis on the G-wagons.

Victorian Nationals leader Danny O'Brien slammed the Labor government for grounding the vehicles before fire season.

"It's only literally ... October 3, (that) the Premier was talking about the upcoming fire season, highlighting that it's going to be potentially a difficult fire season," Mr O'Brien said.

"If that's the case, we need to have every available asset that we can. The government needs to come out today and explain what the implications of that are, how they're dealing with it and how they're going to get those firefighting vehicles back on-stream."

FFMVic reportedly brought additional vehicles online for bushfire season preparedness and in the event of an emergency.

Mr O'Brien, who is also the opposition spokesperson for emergency services, said he was particularly concerned the retirement of the fleet would mean a reliance on Country Fire Authority volunteers.

A CFA spokesperson said the organisation has been working closely with partners to prepare for the summer.

"Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) has been keeping CFA informed of the progress of the current fleet repairs, and we have assisted FFMV with the provision of fire vehicles that were due to go to disposal," the spokesperson said. "CFA will assist FFMV as we always have, in a joint and complementary manner."

Mr O'Brien also pointed to the emergency services and volunteers fund levy, which came into effect on July 1, 2025 .

"Victorians are paying an additional $3 billion through Labor's new emergency services tax," he said. "Yet the CFA is relying on ageing vehicles and is now being asked to cover for FFMVic, an organisation now being funded by these additional taxes."

A protest against the emergency services levy at Chesney Vale in the North East. Picture by Mark Jesser

urn:contentItem:6H31-8523-RSR8-53SC-00000-00History lesson up in smoke2025-10-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 18History lesson up in smoke

It was British Prime Minister Winston Churchill who warned "those who fail to learn from history are doomed to repeat it".

History has repeatedly taught rural and regional Victorians, living in one of the most fire-prone regions on earth, that fuel reduction burns are crucial to saving lives and properties. In fact it was Justice Stretton, who oversaw the Royal Commission into the devastating 1939 fires, who first warned the amount of prescribed burning done by the then Forests Commission was "ridiculously inadequate because of a staff shortage and a tardy recognition of the importance of preventive measures".

Since then other inquiries have echoed that warning, including the 2009 Royal Commission that reported: "The State has maintained a minimalist approach to prescribed burning despite a number of recent official or independent reports and inquiries, all of which have recommended increasing the prescribed burning program." Yet Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan and predecessor Daniel Andrews have failed to learn the lessons of the state's fire history. The government's own reports show the annual area of prescribed burns has halved under Labor's 10 years' in power. That cut has come amid a massive hike in government tax revenue, which has grown from $16.5bn in 2013-14 to an estimated $41.56bn in the 2025-26 Budget. But rather than increasing resources to Forest Fire Management Victoria to undertake more fuel reduction burns, the government has cut its funding. Premier Allan and her colleagues better hope they don't end up before yet another Royal Commission to explain their inaction.

"CFA will assist FFMV as we always have, in a joint and complementary manner."

Mr O'Brien also pointed to the emergency services and volunteers fund levy, which came into effect on July 1, 2025 , in his criticism of the Labor government.

"Victorians are paying an additional $3 billion through Labor's new emergency services tax," he said.

"Yet the CFA is relying on ageing vehicles and is now being asked to cover for FFMVic, an organisation now being funded by these additional taxes."

Victorian Nationals leader Danny O'Brien has slammed the grounding of the vehicles with summer just around the corner. File pictures by Mark Jesser

urn:contentItem:6H63-D913-RVK2-33VK-00000-0035 interstate fire trucks scrambled for Victoria2025-11-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexis35 interstate fire trucks scrambled for Victoria

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Peter Hunt

Forest Fire Management Victoria sent out an appeal to borrow up to 30 tankers from the NSW Rural Fire Service and another five from the SA Country Fire Service, to offset the grounding of its G-wagons and Unimogs.

A NSW RFS spokesman said it "was approached by FFMVic to identify any available firefighting vehicles that could be loaned".

"The RFS has offered a mix of light and medium tankers that are in the process of being decommissioned and are surplus to current operational requirements. FFMVic has not yet indicated whether they intend to accept any of the vehicles offered.

"The proposed support involves vehicles that will not affect the RFS's preparedness or firefighting capability in NSW."

The SA CFS confirmed it was supplying five vehicles.

Sources close to the fire services said FFM had sought the interstate vehicles in the wake of discovering cracks in the chassis of its own 290 G-Wagons and structural issues in its 60 Unimogs.

Most of the FFMVic vehicles have to undergo rigorous inspections before returning to service, with sources saying two G-Wagons had already been written off as their chassis could not be repaired.

Opposition public land management spokeswoman Melina Bath said borrowing interstate vehicles was "further evidence of the chaos that is occurring within our fire services ahead of a dangerous fire season".

She said Environment Minister Steve Dimopoulos "keeps assuring us that everything is fine and that having around 350 FFMV trucks offline has had no impact on our firefighting capability.

"Now we learn they're on a scavenging expedition interstate to try and fill the gaps. The least the Labor Government can do is be transparent with Victorians and answer some basic questions - how many trucks will be written off, what is the cost of this failure and when will all trucks or their replacements be back in service."

The Victorian government would not confirm how many firefighting vehicles it intended to borrow from interstate, but did state Victorian taxpayers were covering the operational cost of running interstate tankers.

The government also stated bushfire response agencies regularly shared fleets.

However industry leaders contacted by this publication said that while interstate crews and their vehicles often came to each other's aid, it was rare for agencies to simply hand over vehicles.

The office of Minister Dimopoulos, who is responsible for FFMVic resourcing, said: "The Victorian community remains well protected from the threat of bushfire due to the incredible work of all our agencies - CFA, FRV, VICSES and FFMVic.

"The safety of our firefighters is paramount, that's why regular safety inspections of vehicles and equipment are so important.

"FFMVic has brought online additional vehicles to continue undertaking critical bushfire season preparations and respond to bushfire emergencies."

FFMVic is also fitting old slip-on units at its depots to vehicles in a bid to rebuild capacity.

urn:contentItem:6GXR-VGH3-RSJY-54KY-00000-00State's frontline fire fleet crippled2025-10-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3State's frontline fire fleet crippledEXCLUSIVE Shannon Deery

Victoria's forest firefighting capability has been crippled just weeks before the fire season with dozens of response -vehicles pulled off the road due to safety concerns.

The Herald Sun can reveal Forest Fire Management Victoria has been forced to ground its entire G-Wagon fleet and multiple heavy tanker Unimog vehicles that have been found with "subframe cracks", raising questions about their roadworthiness.

Authorities have been working since Saturday to put back- up plans in place, and have considered calling on extra CFA support, a move that threatens to stretch already overworked brigades.

Problems with the vehicles - used by Forest Fire Management Victoria for rapid -responses to outbreaks and to access remote terrain - were identified on -Friday, just one day after Premier Jacinta Allan warned that Victoria was heading -towards a significantly dangerous fire season.

"The advice we are receiving as a government is that this is one of the most dangerous seasons we are heading into for some time," she said then.

The vehicles were rolled out from 2017 as part of a $32m -upgrade of the state's firefighting vehicles.

Opposition emergency services spokesman Danny O'Brien said Victorians needed to know what contingencies were in place to protect communities.

"Labor promised Victorians a state-of-the-art firefighting fleet; eight years later Labor has delivered a world-class failure," Mr O'Brien said. "When the Premier warns of a dangerous fire season, Victorians -deserve answers on how this failure was allowed to -happen and what steps will be taken to ensure community safety.

"Victorians are paying an additional $3bn through Labor's new emergency services tax, yet the CFA is relying on ageing vehicles and is now being asked to cover for FFMV, an organisation now being funded by these additional taxes." Opposition public land management spokeswoman Melina Bath slammed the government for leaving regional Victoria exposed.

"Grounding Victoria's frontline fleet weeks before fire season is an unacceptable failure, given nearly 40 per cent of the state is public land," Ms Bath said. "Victorians are paying more but getting less protection." A government spokesman confirmed safety checks had identified issues on almost 300 vehicles, with repairs to be "fast-tracked over the next two months".

"The safety of our firefighters is paramount, that's why regular safety inspections of vehicles and equipment are so important," he said.

"FFMVic has already completed its bushfire preparedness work for the coming season and has the vehicle capacity to respond in a bushfire emergency." The spokesman said a contingency fleet was available as well as Landcruiser vehicles, Fire Tankers and bulldozers. VICSES and CFA had also provided vehicles.

urn:contentItem:6H0N-K333-S3X8-J3TG-00000-00Missing man 'thought I was a dead duck'2025-10-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisWNEWSPg. 30Missing man 'thought I was a dead duck'Liam Beatty

A man who vanished while on a camping trip with his wife has been rescued after days spent stranded in the Victorian wilderness.

Troy Milne, 61, went missing after leaving a caravan park in Woodside Beach, southeast of Melbourne, for a short supply run in his Jeep Wrangler on the afternoon of October 7. What should have been a quick trip spiralled into a missing person case spanning a huge area in the state's east.

Police issued a public appeal on October 12, citing "deep concerns" the insulin-dependent diabetic could be lost and confused. "I thought I was a dead duck in water ... I just drank lots of water," Mr Milne told 9News.

He was found in remote bushland near Buchan on Thursday night after Forest Fire Management Victoria staff responded to a fire near Kirby Cross Track about 5pm.

"On arrival, fire crews spotted the Jeep Wrangler on the unmarked track adjacent to the fire and subsequently located Troy nearby," Victoria Police spokesman Acting Inspector Kris Hamilton said.

"Troy's vehicle had bottomed out on the terrain and was not drivable. As a result, the 61-year-old lit a fire in the hope emergency services would respond." Wellington Police Service Area Inspector Wayne Rothwell said finding Mr Milne alive was a "remarkable outcome". "We really feared the worst, so to be able to contact Troy's family and give them the fantastic news was a wonderful result," he said. He said Troy was without his medication for a long period, "which left him disorientated and confused".

urn:contentItem:6H0G-25G3-RRJD-94X6-00000-00Missing man Troy Milne found alive in bushland more than two hours from campsite2025-10-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisMissing man Troy Milne found alive in bushland more than two hours from campsiteBy Madeleine Stuchbery and Zaida Glibanovic  

A man who was missing in Victoria's east for more than a week is recovering in hospital after being found in bushland when he started a fire to draw attention to his location.

A man who went missing for more than a week in Victorian bushland has been found by police, more than two hours away from his campsite.

61-year-old Troy Milne, from Cockatoo, was camping with his wife at Woodside Beach in the state's south-east when he went missingwhile picking up supplies on October 7. 

He was found around 5pm on Thursday evening in Buchan in East Gippsland after an extensive nine-day search operation.

Police had concerns for Mr Milne's health, as he is an insulin-dependent diabetic. 

He was discovered near his Jeep Wrangler close to the Kirby Cross Track after Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) responded to reports of a fire. 

Wellington Police Service Area Inspector Wayne Rothwell said he was found dehydrated, but was OK. 

"His medical condition caused him to become confused," Inspector Rothwell said. 

"He visited a number of towns asking for directions back to Sale, the last location was at Omeo then he headed down the Great Alpine Road and was sighted on CCTV at Swifts Creek." 

[MAP]

Inspector Rothwell said it appeared the missing man had taken a track off the Great Alpine Road and moved through bush towards Buchan. 

He was found with his vehicle, which had bottomed out on a rut on the track. 

"It appears Troy has lit a fire to bring attention to himself," Inspector Rothwell said. 

Mr Milne has been taken to hospital for treatment and observation.

urn:contentItem:6H13-94M3-SJ80-B2RS-00000-00Some scientists challenge logic of Victoria's fuel reduction burns2025-10-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisSome scientists challenge logic of Victoria's fuel reduction burns

Dry winter conditions have resulted in extra fuel reduction burns in regional Victoria ahead of the fire season. But some scientists are asking if fuel burns are the best way to reduce fire risk. 

Planned burns are a cornerstone of Australian bushfire preparedness. 

And a dry winter in regional Victoria throughout 2025 has presented forest fire management teams with opportunities for extra fuel load reduction burns. 

But as Victorians brace for heightened fire risks this summer, particularly in western and south-western regions of the state, a growing chorus of ecologists and environmentalists is challenging the planned burns methodology.

Some say planned burns are causing more harm than good, with resources better directed to new technologies and a more bespoke approach to fuel reduction ahead of the fire season. 

Country Fire Authority (CFA) assistant chief fire officer Brian Russell said conditions, particularly in South Gippsland, had been dry during winter and into spring. 

He said while rain was on the way this spring, it was "not going to make a big difference". 

"The fire danger is still there," Mr Russell said. 

"As soon as we get a bit of sun and a bit of wind, we will have those fire conditions again."

Peter Brick is a regional manager for Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) in Gippsland. 

He said autumn and winter presented opportunities to undertake extra fuel reduction in the state. 

"We were able to treat nearly 40,000 hectares of public lands across 81 different planned burns," he said.

"They'll provide immediate benefit this summer to reduce the risk of bushfire to the community." 

Other fuel reduction works conducted throughout winter include fuel break maintenance, roadside slashing, and track maintenance. 

Mr Brick said planned burns had a role to play in reducing fire risk, particularly around houses and communities. 

"But we also burn further out across the landscape, and those larger landscapes really give firefighters a chance to get there, and keep fires small," he said.

'It isn't the simple fix'

Planned burns have been used in Victoria since the late 1930s to manage bushfire risk.

But it is a mode of fire fuel load management that some have been pushing back on. 

Australian National University professorDavid Lindenmayer has published more than 1,442 scientific works, and is an expert in forest ecology and resource management.

He has questioned the practicality of using burns as a fuel reduction technique, and said there was evidence showing planned burning could increase fire risk instead of reducing it.

"The evidence to support prescribed burning is actually remarkably thin," Professor Lindenmayer said. 

He said the vigorous nature of regrowth after a fire created flammable material, whereas older forest material was less flammable, known as disturbance-stimulated flammability.

He said while burns did work for a short window of time — about five years — the system could become more flammable for 40 to 50 years after. 

"It generally has limited effect under extreme fire weather conditions," he said. 

"It costs a lot of money and has limited effectiveness when we are most likely to lose houses under extreme fire weather.

"The aim of the game is to reduce fire risk, but in some cases ... prescribed burning could be making it worse in the medium to long-term." 

Professor Lindenmayer said turning to new technologies, such as firefighting drones which can quickly reach remote fires while they are small, could be a better way to mitigate fire risk. 

"You can do it within 5 to 10 minutes if you've got the right density of drones."

With more than 20 years' experience monitoring forest ecosystems, ecologist Karl Just has conducted more than 1,000 fuel hazard assessments using Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action (DEECA) and FFMVic methods. 

"Planned burning isn't the simple fix it's often made out to be," Mr Just said. 

"In most forests, it only lowers fuels for two or three years before regrowth makes things worse.

"Fire actually triggers dense shrub growth that can last decades, meaning long-unburnt forests often end up with less fuel than those burned more frequently." 

Mr Just said planned burning should remain part of future fuel reduction strategies, but studies showed most risk reduction happened within 50 metres around homes and not by burning in remote bushland.

'We use science' 

But authorities say Gippsland's fuel-driven bushfire risk is well within the target range, off the back of opportunities to carry out risk reduction works through 2023-24. 

FFMVic chief fire officer Chris Hardman said its bushfire risk management program was underpinned by a significant body of evidence and the department continued to invest in research and the best science. 

"We use science and modelling tools to choose the right time and approach to deliver our bushfire risk management program, including planned burns, mowing, slashing and spraying," he said. 

"We know from both research and practical experience that fuel management slows the spread of fire, and helps firefighters reduce threats to communities, critical infrastructure and the environment."

urn:contentItem:6G3T-NM93-RST2-353R-00000-00'Colossal failure': Magistrate roasts arsonist after state forest fire2025-06-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexis'Colossal failure': Magistrate roasts arsonist after state forest fire

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Toni Moon and Janine Watson

A Mid-North Coast gardener-turned-arsonist has been roasted by a magistrate for starting and feeding a state forest fire which had the "potential to cause disastrous catastrophe and loss of life."

Coffs Harbour Court heard on Monday Jarrod Fenech, 24, torched Nambucca State Forest on January 7 last year while running a lawn-mowing business.

Fenech - who is on a pension and diagnosed with anxiety - was slammed by Magistrate Michael O'Brien whose words boomed across the court over the "poor decision" which burned approximately 70 sqm of bushland.

"This is a colossal moment of failure - learn from it," Mr O'Brien said.

"Each summer we are assaulted by dreadful stories of loss of life and loss of property," he said.

He said the community would be "quietly enraged" that someone would think starting a fire was "a fun way to spend time".

As the tirade against Fenech continued, the Magistrate said the arson was committed with a co-accused.

"It's easy to stand up to your enemies but it's hard to stand up to your friends," he said.

"Say no, be better than that."

Fenech, who pleaded guilty to intentionally causing a fire and being reckless to its spread, was sentenced to a two-year Community Corrections Order and 100 hours of community service.

The sentence was on par with that of co-accused Tim Leigh, 26, who also received a two-year CCO when he appeared before court in January.

Got a news tip? Email: toni.moon@news.com.au

urn:contentItem:6H4H-2HH3-RWDT-1363-00000-00Ash Wednesday repeat: alarm at lag in burn-offs2025-11-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisTHENATIONPg. 6Ash Wednesday repeat: alarm at lag in burn-offsJOHN FERGUSON, ASSOCIATE EDITOR, EXCLUSIVE

Many thousands of hectares of highly volatile bushfire country across a broad area hit by the Ash Wednesday disaster remain unburnt in Victoria's Otway Ranges, as the window for planned controls narrows ahead of summer.

Official Allan government figures show fire agencies are making slow progress this year in the drive to implement planned burns in an area ripe for a major fire disaster that includes one of Australia's busiest summer tourist regions.

Blazes on Ash Wednesday in 1983 - when 75 people died in Victoria and South Australia - torched hundreds of houses in or near the the Otway Ranges including at Aireys Inlet, Moggs Creek, and the Anglesea area, killing three.

Forest Fire Management Victoria data for planned burns shows that in some areas of the Otways, which shadow the Great Ocean Road, there are many thousands of hectares still to be burnt this financial year with extensive burn-offs needed to reach targets. In some cases the official data says no burning has occurred in 2025.

The Allan government is under pressure from fire experts for slashing the amount of planned burn-offs compared with the recommendation of the Black Saturday bushfires royal commission. Planned burn-offs need to be conducted outside the most intense fire conditions in summer and are usually achieved in spring and autumn.

FFMV says that planned burn-offs are conducted over a three-year period and that if targets are missed they are carried over to the next year. The burn-offs are listed as 2025 but FFMV says this means the current financial year.

FFMV acting chief fire officer Scott Turner said the state's emergency services were well-placed this season.

"FFMV crews use every opportunity possible to reduce the risk and impact of bushfires through planned burning, when conditions are not suitable we deliver non-burn works including mulching, mowing, spraying, constructing fuel breaks and maintaining road access for firefighting," Mr Turner said.

The Howitt Society has warned that the halving of burn-offs and other measures since Labor was elected in 2014 had set the scene for fire disasters that could match or exceed this year's Los Angeles disaster, when about 30 people died and more than 17,000 homes and buildings were razed.

The Otways is about 160km southwest of Melbourne and has more than 100,000 hectares. It is a high rainfall area, which can further complicate attempts to make planned burn-offs.

At Christmas in 2015, 116 houses were burned at Wye River and Separation Creek, as a bushfire burned for 34 days.

Howitt Society secretary Garry Squires has warned that the lack of burning off meant areas such as the Dandenongs, Yarra Valley, Otways and Mornington Peninsula were exposed to potential disasters.

On Black Saturday in 2009, 173 people died in Victoria, prompting the 2010 royal commission, which backed a then doubling of prescribed burns to 5 per cent of public land.

Successive governments failed to implement fully the royal commission's demands for fire refuges across the state.

Opposition public land spokeswoman Melina Bath said the government had no control over the weather or daily fire conditions but it could influence fuel loads. "The only thing that they can control is the fuel loads," Ms Bath said. She has questioned the decision of Labor to ignore the royal commission recommendation on doubling planned burn-offs and also the broader manner in which fire services have been treated in Victoria.

urn:contentItem:6H4H-2HH3-RWDT-13T0-00000-00Fire strategy must face our new reality2025-11-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisLETTERSPg. 21Fire strategy must face our new reality

It's clear from your graph that prescribed burning in Victoria has declined over the past decade (On the backburner, TWT, Oct 29).

As you note, Victoria is "one of the most fire-prone regions on earth" and we should learn from the past (History lesson up in smoke, TWT, Oct 29). But how relevant is that past?

Since the 1939 fires, atmospheric CO2 has risen by over 100 parts per million - around 36 per cent - driving global warming. Southern Australia has dried, and safe burning windows are narrowing.

This year, the CFA extended the fire season to May in the southwest, while it has already begun in the northwest and southeast, with warnings of conditions similar to those before the 2019-20 fires.

The 2020 royal commission did not recommend expanding prescribed burning. In evidence, Professor Jason Staples said reducing fuel loads "may have no appreciable effect under extreme conditions". New research also shows prescribed burning can make forests more flammable, while old, unburnt forests are less so. Forest fire management must adapt to the new climatic reality. Rapid detection and suppression should be the focus.

Sarah Brennan, Hawthorn Net-zero neglect As someone from a farming family, I know that weather, climate, and water supply are the foundation of life on the land. That's why it matters that polling shows 70 per cent of farmers and regional Australians support policies that reduce climate pollution (Quiet majority of rural Australia backs clean energy, new survey reveals, TWT, Jan 26, 2024).

The National Party says it stands for rural communities. But if it walks away from net-zero commitments and ignores the growing risks of drought, water shortages, and unpredictable seasons, how is that helping farmers? (Barnaby sits net-zero talks out as Nationals close in on policy, TWT, Oct 29). We need leadership that reflects what's happening on the ground. Climate action isn't about politics - it's about protecting our farms, our livelihoods and our future.

Amy Hiller, Kew Coalition drift By stepping away from climate and energy targets, the National Party is confirming that they don't care about the climate disasters hurting rural and regional communities across Australia.

If National Party politicians cared about climate impacts, they would have policies to help those who have already suffered from extreme fires, storms and floods.

Where is the Coalition's plan to keep regional communities safe and prosperous? Larni Dibben, Glen Iris Nuclear folly Targets aside, what is the Coalition's energy policy? It seems those pushing to abolish the target are hoping to convince the electorate that our shift to renewables is too expensive. What, then, to make of the fact that they are still wedded to the most expensive option: nuclear?

If one nuclear reactor was built by, say, 2045, it would provide a tiny fraction (1 gigawatt) of our projected electricity needs. It would be hugely expensive to build and make hugely expensive electricity (to consumers).

Meanwhile, rooftop solar already gives us 11.3 per cent of our electricity supply; in the first half of 2024, total capacity reached 24.4GW.

Fiona Colin, Malvern East Deer hypocrisy Context counts (High deer hunt rates to expand, TWT, Oct 29). The deer "harvest" rose to 167,000 last year, but Victoria is estimated to have more than a million feral deer. So the hunters left well over 800,000 to breed up.

The Game Management Authority report says hunting "efficiency" increased. But its most startling statistic is that half of the 52,000 deer hunting licences were not used. Why get a licence then? Perhaps to justify gun ownership. It seems hunting licences are too cheap.

For most Victorians, deer are an escalating pest - damaging private property and native habitat, and causing accidents on our roads. Deer should be humanely culled, not preserved for entertainment.

Pat Smith, Doncaster Global headwinds ï»¿The rise of AI, mandatory climate and nature-related disclosures, changing societal expectations and "carbon border adjustments" (Fertiliser tariff fear, TWT, Oct 22) at home and abroad, will all have consequences for agriculture.

Global conflicts and de-globalisation making demand less predictable, along with biosecurity issues and a changing climate will mean farmers must deal with even more unpredictability than they famously have historically.

Lesley Walker, Northcote

urn:contentItem:6H43-40P3-RRVV-D1TV-00000-00Burn-off fiasco risks LA repeat2025-11-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisTHENATIONPg. 6Burn-off fiasco risks LA repeatJOHN FERGUSON ASSOCIATE EDITOR

Australia's most exposed bushfire areas are facing Los Angeles or Black Saturday-style community disasters because of a failure to -accept royal commission -demands on burn-offs.

Bushfire experts say Victoria's neglect to come anywhere near burning off targets set by the Black Saturday royal commission has exposed large areas to crippling fires, including heavily populated centres.

The Howitt Society has warned that the halving of burn-offs and other mitigation measures under Labor since 2014 has set the scene for potential dis-asters that would rival the impact of this year's Los Angeles fires where more than 17,000 homes, businesses and other buildings were destroyed.

While about 30 people died, the fires were dwarfed in human terms by the 2009 Black Saturday fires in Victoria where 173 people died.

Howitt Society secretary Garry Squires said Victoria was meant to burn off 5 per cent of public land each year to reduce fuel loads under the royal commission recommendation. The Australian has calculated that number was running at about 1.5 per cent in 2023-24, the estimation based on publicly available information.

Mr Squires warned that NSW was also exposed and there was broad risk of another disaster in Victoria: "It just could go wrong." He said this meant the fire risk had soared and that heavily populated areas in Victoria including the Dandenongs, Yarra Valley, Otway Ranges and Mornington Peninsula were at high risk.

Asked whether the Victorian government had done enough, he said: "It certainly has not." Fire safety is looming as a potentially major issue at the next Victorian election after Labor overhauled fire fighting services and imposed an unpopular fire services tax.

Forest Fire Management Victoria is working in an environment of extreme budget pressure but with a growing population that continues to encroach on rural areas, especially in the interface zones outside Melbourne.

The Black Saturday royal commission backed a then doubling of prescribed burn-offs to 5 per cent of public land but Victoria deemed in 2016 that the target was not achievable.

Climate variability has also reduced the window of opportunity for burning off in the nearly nine million hectares of public land.

Opposition public land spokeswoman Melina Bath said Labor's failure to manage fuel loads had been an act of "reckless -complacency".

"Labor's neglect of Victoria's public forests is a disaster waiting to happen; its fuel reduction program has collapsed from around 200,000ha to barely 100,000ha," the Nationals MP said.

"Labor stopped fuel load mapping in 2020, leaving communities completely in the dark. Regional Victorians live with the consequences of Labor's mismanagement each and every fire season." The hardest hit areas on Black Saturday in 2009 included Marysville on the edge of the Yarra -Ranges, where 34 people died and hundreds of buildings, mainly houses, were wiped out .

The fire season in Victoria, South Australian and Tasmania - typically the worst areas in Australia - tends to start later in the season compared with Queensland and NSW.

The severity of the season will hinge on full loads, dryness of the fuel, temperature on any day, wind severity and topography.

Victoria's Dandenong Ranges and Otway National Forest are well overdue for major fires, potentially affecting thousands of people.

Acting FFMVic chief fire officer Scott Turner said emergency services were well-prepared "for all emerging risks" linked to an earlier bushfire season.

He said FFMVic used every possible time to cut the risk through planned burns and other so-called mechanical means such as mowing, spraying, fuel breaks and maintaining road access.

"Reducing bushfire risk occurs throughout the year," he said. "Our long-term strategy focuses on building a strategic network of fuel-reduced areas across public land, not just through one burn or one year, but through ongoing planned action." Risk minimisation also focused on emergency warning systems and community engagement.

A core issue in the royal commission report was the lack of proper communications systems, especially around fire locations. Since Black Saturday, an inevitable sense of complacency has hit some areas, especially among so-called tree changers, who have -arrived in areas that are impossible to defend.

urn:contentItem:6GY2-8683-RRVV-929K-00000-00Warnings issued as campers ignore bans2025-10-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisNews13Warnings issued as campers ignore bansAmy Rees

'Over the long weekend, I personally put out four fires'.

IGNORANCE is not an excuse when it comes to lighting campfires during fire ban periods, with the results costly and potentially deadly.

Over the October long weekend, Forestry Corporation ranger Paul Robb put out four campfires that were burning, despite a solid fuel fire ban coming into effect on October 1. Mr Robb said he came across fires in Sunny Corner, Vulcan, Jenolan, and Lisdale State Forests.

This is Mr Robb's third October long weekend patrolling the region's state forests, and each year he has come across people lighting campfires.

"It happens every year... it is very frustrating," he said. "Over the long weekend, I personally put out four fires that were burning. People just claimed they weren't aware."

Mr Robb said ignorance won't save people from having to pay the $550 on-the-spot fine, which is given to everyone sitting around and using the fire, not just the person who lit it. In addition to the fine, people are also liable for any damage their campfire causes if it becomes out of control. And with plantations worth approximately $140,000 per hectare, a simple weekend away could end up costly.

But the biggest cost of all is the safety of forest users. Mr Robb said an out-of-control forest fire becomes very dangerous very quickly, to everyone in the forest at the time.

"People don't realise the danger they put themselves and other forest users in, let alone the damage to our business," he said. "We're responsible for all forest users, but we're also responsible to the business. It's a taxpayer business of pine plantation. So we're responsible for looking after that asset for the taxpayer, and if it gets burnt, that's not a good thing."

Until April 30 - subject to fire conditions - no solid fuel, wood fires or little ovens are permitted in state forests. Mr Paul said campers can only use gas appliances, and even then, cannot leave them unattended at any time.

urn:contentItem:6GVP-VXK3-RSRC-H4CY-00000-00Firefighter's warning as off-season grassfire burns out of control2025-09-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisFirefighter's warning as off-season grassfire burns out of control

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Timothy Cox

A grassfire burnt out of control near Ballarat on Monday afternoon, prompting an unusually large emergency response for the pre-fire season period.

A CFA spokesman said 27 crews and 90 personnel in total were called to tackle the grass and scrubfire that broke out near Berringa about 1.30pm.

"Crews discovered a large grassfire producing a significant amount of smoke,'' the spokesman said.

"The grassfire is located in difficult terrain."

Air support and Forest Fire Management Victoria were called to the scene to assist.

VicEmergency listed a watch and act for residents in Berringa, Cape Clear, Springdallah as the fire moved southeast from Moonlight Creek Rd towards Derwent Jacks and Staffordshire Reef Roads.

Strong winds and dangerous trees slowed down firefighers' efforts early on.

As of Monday afternoon, about 10ha had been burnt on the private parcel of land.

The fire was deemed under control at 6.24pm and safe at 8.18pm.

CFA incident controller and Grenville Group officer Greg Parker said investigations continued regarding the cause of the fire.

"Obviously at the moment there's a lot of people that are burning off in the area trying to clean up before the fire danger period and fire season takes effect, so people just need to be mindful and make sure that they black out their fires prior to leaving, especially if it is a weekender that lives elsewhere," he said.

"The number of appliances and the area that it's burnt is very unusual for this time of year, being so early.

"But the bush and areas are still quite dry because of the lack of rainfall across the area."

CFA members have already begun preparations for the fire season.

urn:contentItem:6GXV-8TB3-RS93-M4YH-00000-00When camping trips turn costly: warnings issued as campers ignore fire ban2025-10-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisWhen camping trips turn costly: warnings issued as campers ignore fire banAmy Rees

'Over the long weekend, I personally put out four fires'.

IGNORANCE is not an excuse when it comes to lighting campfires during fire ban periods, with the results costly and potentially deadly.

Over the October long weekend, Forestry Corporation ranger Paul Robb put out four campfires that were burning, despite a solid fuel fire ban coming into effect on October 1.

Mr Robb said he came across fires in Sunny Corner, Vulcan, Jenolan, and Lisdale State Forests.

This is Mr Robb's third October long weekend patrolling the region's state forests, and each year he has come across people lighting campfires.

"It happens every year ... it is very frustrating," he said.

"Over the long weekend, I personally put out four fires that were burning.

"People just claimed they weren't aware."

Mr Robb said ignorance won't save people from having to pay the $550 on-the-spot fine, which is given to everyone sitting around and using the fire, not just the person who lit it.

In addition to the fine, people are also liable for any damage their campfire causes if it becomes out of control.

And with plantations worth approximately $140,000 per hectare, a simple weekend away could end up costly.

But the biggest cost of all is the safety of forest users.

Mr Robb said an out-of-control forest fire becomes very dangerous very quickly, to everyone in the forest at the time.

"People don't realise the danger they put themselves and other forest users in, let alone the damage to our business," he said.

"We're responsible for all forest users, but we're also responsible to the business.

"It's a taxpayer business of pine plantation. So we're responsible for looking after that asset for the taxpayer, and if it gets burnt, that's not a good thing."

From October 1 until April 30 - subject to fire conditions - no solid fuel, wood fires or little ovens are permitted in state forests.

Mr Paul said campers can only use gas appliances, and even then, cannot leave them unattended at any time.

He asks that people enjoying the forests for their recreational activities simply follow the regulations, for the safety of themselves, others and the plantation.

Forestry Corporation ranger Paul Robb reminds forest users the fire ban has commenced. Picture supplied

urn:contentItem:6GVX-JFF3-RRR6-F0KR-00000-00Cause of fire at Berringa under investigation after evacuation warning2025-10-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisCause of fire at Berringa under investigation after evacuation warningAdam Spencer

It was the first major blaze ahead of the fire season.

Fire investigations are looking for the cause of a grass and scrub fire at Berringa, south of Ballarat, after an evacuation warning was issued to residents on Monday afternoon.

The fire, on Derwent Jacks Road, ignited just after 1pm on September 29, with 30 CFA units called to the scene about 1.16pm.

A CFA spokesperson said the fire was in difficult terrain, spanned across 10 acres and was producing a significant amount of smoke.

"Forest Fire Management Victoria were called to the scene to assist," the spokesperson said.

" A Watch and Act, and Advice warning was issued to the community to stay near shelter and stay Informed.

"A fire investigator has been called to the scene and investigations are still underway."

The CFA said no assets were under threat and the scene was deemed under control at 6.24pm.

It was the first major blaze of the season, coming just weeks after the CFA urged residents in bushfire-prone areas to get a bushfire plan in place and start preparing their properties for the summer.

It also comes as the hay season begins in the western part of Victoria, with farmers being urged to take extra care to prevent haystack fires.

Haystack fires are often caused by spontaneous combustion when hay is baled with excess moisture.

High moisture levels, combined with the compact nature of hay bales, can create internal heat, leading to ignition.

In the 2024/25 financial year, the CFA said it responded to 73 haystack and hay shed fires in regional areas, with 53 per cent occurring in the west and northwest of the state.

A CFA truck near the scene of a grass and scrub fire in Berringa, south-west of Ballarat on September 29, 2025. Picture by Michelle Smith

urn:contentItem:6H3N-5N53-S7FP-X4R3-00000-00BREAKING BARRIERS2025-11-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisLIFESTYLEPg. 7BREAKING BARRIERSTESSA HAYWARD

TYSON NEAL-EDWARDS IS RUNNING IN THE NEW YORK CITY MARATHON TOMORROW, BUT HE TELLS TESSA HAYWARD THE REAL JOURNEY STARTS WHEN HE FINISHES IT The sound of his feet hitting the pavement is all that Tyson Neal-Edwards hears when he is running.

There's no music blaring through headphones or any distractions. Instead, this is his time to think.

Six months ago, the 23-year-old had never even considered running a marathon, let alone going on runs consistently.

But his decision to apply for the Indigenous Marathon Project (IMP) Squad, and be selected first go, changed everything.

The proud Gunditjmara, Wadawurrung and Arrernte man will take on the New York City Marathon tomorrow as part of the IMP Squad of inspiring First Nations runners and changemakers who are breaking barriers, building leadership and creating healthier futures through running.

But as Tyson explains, being a part of the IMP Squad is so much more than just running a marathon.

"It is a leadership and development program at its core," he says. To apply for the six-month program, applicants must not have run a marathon before and be aged between 18 and30.

Twelve Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander people are then selected to train for the New York City Marathon.

Education is a compulsory part of the program, which is run by the Indigenous Marathon Foundation, and includes education on leadership, first aid, mental health and media training.

Physical and mental boundaries are pushed to a new level and the marathon is used to support members to realise that they can achieve anything.

Tyson, who works in forest fire management, says he initially applied as he liked networking with mob and like-minded people.

"Being in the program has changed my why significantly, it has been a very emotional journey," he shares.

"I am the oldest of seven siblings and I want to lead by action. Action speaks louder than words so I want to do my best and show them that.

"You can be what you can't see, they don't have to run marathons, but you can do anything." Training for the marathon started six months ago and Tyson says they started with the Mother's Day Classic 10km in Canberra in May, followed by half marathons on the Gold Coast and Sunshine Coast.

The 30km election run in Alice Springs was their final challenge, It was the most emotional for Tyson, with both his nan and sister there supporting him.

If all these runs are completed, you are selected to go to New York. "It's been pretty hard, challenging in a few aspects, not just physically but mentally. It is all mental," Tyson says.

"I've learned mostly that this has given me the opportunity to share my story. Being in this program has taught me how to tell it and that's what the program is about, telling your story, who you are and why you should be here.

"Out of all the things you get out of the program, running the marathon is not at the top." Tyson admits he is nervous for the marathon, but is excited to travel with the squad to New York for 10 days.

The program, which was founded by former world champion Rob de Castella, is kept short to keep it challenging.

"Other people in the squad have been through so much, they give me hope," Tyson says, adding ambassadors like NRL legend Johnathan Thurston and AFL superstar Lance "Buddy" Franklin have been on the six-month journey too.

"It is really life-changing and not just for me, it impacts my family in healthy choices and empowerment.

"Uncle Rob says it's not about taking 12 black fellas to New York, instead the journey starts at the end of the marathon." Tyson, who has lived in Geelong his whole life, has spent a lot of time at the Wathaurong Aboriginal Co-operative in North Geelong, which his Pop Trevor Edwards founded and his nan played a pivotal role in.

"It was founded by my grandfather purely because Geelong had the largest number of stolen generation mob in the state, they had no place to go," Tyson says, adding his nan was part of the stolen generation.

"That trauma has trickled down to mum but it stops with me, I want to do good for my family." His mum recently got to watch him finish the half marathon in Melbourne, which was very emotional for them both.

"She's a single mum and has raised us herself. I do everything I can for her and to help her," he says fondly.

When it comes to hitting the pavement Tyson says he will never listen to music. "I thoroughly enjoy that part of the day when I have no distractions, no phone," he says.

"I get to calm down and think about things I didn't want to think about and I love hearing my feet. You get in a flow state," he says.

"I'm so happy I can share my story, particularly for my mum and my nan. They made me who I am today." Follow @kngwarrayee and @indigenousmarathonfoundation on Instagram

urn:contentItem:6H31-8523-RSR8-53TT-00000-00ON THE BACKBURNER2025-10-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1ON THE BACKBURNERPETER HUNT and DAVID JOHNSTON

Years of neglect have left Victorians at risk, in what is shaping up to be one of the worst fire seasons in more than a decade.

A lack of resources has meant a steady decline in fuel reduction burns, which state government records show have slumped from about 200,000ha annually, when Labor came to power in late 2014, to about 100,000ha in recent years.

That decline comes despite the Allan government raking in an extra $540m in fire services tax this financial year.

Howitt Society president Peter Flinn said fuel reduction burns now amounted to little more than 1 per cent of Victoria's public land each year, "just one fifth of the minimum recommended per annum by the royal commission into the horrendous 2009 Black Saturday fires, which claimed 173 lives".

"We are frequently told by FFMV (Forest Fire Management Victoria) they would like to do more in terms of fuel management, but are constrained by a shortage of funds and/or manpower, objections from some sections of the community, and that climate change is 'narrowing the windows' for suitable weather conditions," he said. The government has admitted FFMV funding has fallen from $441.3m 2024-25 to $400.6m this financial year, but stated it was the result of specific project funding for emergency management reforms coming to an end.

However Mr Flinn said the lack of resources meant fuel reduction burns that FFMVic promised to undertake in the Southern Grampians this spring had not occurred, as thousands of tonnes of fuel built up in the canopy and the forest floor.

Further east FFMVic has cleared windblown trees from 1100ha of the 44,700ha Wombat-Lerderderg Forest, but has admitted there are large areas where thousands of logs remain lying on the forest floor from 2021 storms.

Bush User Groups United representative Stephen Smitham said the situation could get a lot worse, once the government locked up 75,000ha of the forest in new parks and reserves, under legislation before Parliament's Upper House this week. "I'd already be worried about going into the forest if I was a CFA volunteer," Mr Smitham said. "But if they lock it up, ban firewood collection and tracks aren't maintained it will get worse." A 2024 University of Melbourne study, titled Throwing fuel on the fire, found hard hit windblown sites in the Wombat Forest had 300 tonnes per hectare of coarse fuels - fallen branches and logs - compared to 20t/ha in undamaged forest, which would result in "a 17-fold increase in total heat output".

FFMVic acting chief Scott Turner said: "The most recent seasonal outlook showed drying conditions for the west and southwest of the state, including the Grampians region and Wombat State Forest.

"When a bushfire starts, we are ready to respond through aggressive first attack to keep fires small." Bureau of Meteorology maps show East Gippsland soil moisture down to a depth of 1m is very much below average, a fact that CFA South East region deputy chief officer Trevor Owen said was "not being appreciated".

Agronomist and Bindi farmer Eddy Mauger said Gippsland's fuel loads were "atrocious because there has been no backburning done this year.

"There is serious, serious scope for a bushfire season up here. If it gets into that regrowth from the 2019-20 fires on the road between Ensay and Bruthen it would go off like a nuclear bomb." As FFMVic struggles to reduce fuel loads the Allan government has almost doubled fire service taxes on Victorian households and businesses, from $839m in 2023-24 to $1.54bn this financial year, with another hike to $1.8bn in 2026-27.

Premier Jacinta Allan and her Treasurer Jaclyn Symes have repeatedly stated "every dollar" of the emergency services volunteer tax would be used to fund emergency services, but have repeatedly refused to detail how much extra is going to FFMVic and the CFA in 2025-26.

When asked to provide details of the CFA's 2025-26 budget, Treasurer Symes office simply stated details would be released in the agency's annual report, which is unlikely to be released until after next year's November 28 state election.

Meanwhile, Victorians have been left in the dark on just how much fuel has built up in forests that cover a third of the state. In 2020 the government stopped publishing fuel load maps for fear they could be used by arsonists, an argument the nation's leading bushfire scientists branded "ludicrous" and "a load of rubbish".

Since then the government has simply reported on statewide and regional fuel-driven bushfire risk reduction targets.

The government has set at a statewide target that equates to reducing the loss of life and property to 70 per cent of what would have occurred if no planned burning or major fires had occurred (100 per cent).

But even then access to the latest 2024-25 risk report has been delayed until December.

The most recent publicly available report for 2023-24 showed the bushfire risk at a regional level had reached 92 per cent in Melbourne's foothills, the Dandenongs and Mornington Peninsula, worse than in the lead-up to the 2009 Black Saturday fires.

When asked to supply the 2024-25 risk reports FFMVic stated they would not be released until December. " Opinion, Page 18

urn:contentItem:6GSR-MBN3-RRKD-C3XT-00000-00Updated: September 18, 2025: Autonomous University of Barcelona Horses, possible allies in forest fire prevention and other recent news2025-09-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSUpdated: September 18, 2025: Autonomous University of Barcelona Horses, possible allies in forest fire prevention and other recent news

The research-which included the participation of Boumort Wildland, the Miranda Foundation, the Forest Horses association, and the University of Barcelona (UB)-reveals that horses adapt their diet according to breed, environment and use. This flexibility helps them play a complementary role alongside other herbivores in sustainable fire prevention strategies, given that their grazing reduces fuel loads and maintains open landscapes. The study was co-authored by researchers from the Department of Animal and Food Science at the UAB Jordi Bartolome and Araceli Gort-Esteve.

"Until now research on extensive herding and forest fire prevention has focused mainly on sheep and goats, with some isolated studies done on breeds of rustic cattle. There have been very few studies on horses within this context, since traditionally they are classified as plant grazers that have little effect on woody vegetations", explains Ariadna Nieto-Espinet, Ramon y Cajal researcher at the UdL and zooarchaeologist. "Our work is one of the first to use empirical data to analyse their potential in forest management in the Mediterannean", she adds.

September 17: The UAB Healthcare Service celebrates its 50th anniversary with a tribute and recognition ceremony

The event, which brought together some one hundred people, was presided by UAB Rector Javier Lafuente, accompanied at the table by Secretary General Esther Zapater, and director of the SAS, Arantza Igartua.

Rector Lafuente welcomed the attendees and emphasised the importance of highlighting the service's track record. Esther Zapater then spoke about the fact that the SAS has been able to adapt to changing times over the course of five decades, incorporating specialties such as gynaecology, dentistry, occupational health and psychology, and demonstrating its ability to respond to critical moments such as the pandemic. The secretary general highlighted the role of proximity and humanity played by the service's staff and also gave thanks to the work carried out by the members of the First Response Teams in Emergency Situations (EPAS), who altruistically and voluntarily assist with first aid in the different UAB centres.

Source: Company Website

SECTION 2 OTHER NEWS: 2025

September 18: Sixty-four internships to explain the UAB to future UABers

If you are a UAB student and want to share your experience with others, this is your chance! We are looking for 64 undergraduate and graduate students interested in explaining the different degrees and services offered at the UAB and solve any doubts future UABers may have.

We offer three different internships, one with 60 places and two more with two places each:

The first is the Promotional activities which consists in 100 hours distributed throughout the months of January and May 2026, and focusing on student participation in activities and events, such as the Education Fair, Open Days, Family Days and other activities, both on-site and online. All of the activities can be found at the #VisitTheUAB website. Students will receive a grant of 746 euros gross in total. A total of 60 placements are offered to students from all faculties and schools, to be able to explain the wide range of academic programmes available at the UAB. You must sign up through Nexus.

September 18: The UAB is sad to announce the death of Josep Llopart

Josep Llopart Barcelo held the position of university manager before continuing his professional career outside the UAB.
