September 18: Barcelona already has its first cycling map

The study is the result of a collaboration between the Institute of Environmental Science and Technology (ICTA-UAB) the Barcelona Supercomputing Center (BSC-CNS) and the Bicycle Club of Catalonia (BACC), with the fundamental support of the public: 43 volunteers collected data through the BiciZen platform, making a more detailed and possible model possible.

It is an innovative tool that allows estimating cycling traffic in more than 20,000 road sections of the city and that opens the door to a much more accurate understanding of cycling mobility patterns.

This information is key to the management of mobility in the city, since for the first time we have a detailed x-ray of cycling flows at street level. In addition, one of the great lessons learned from the project is that citizen participation has been decisive in improving the models: without crowdsourcing, today we would not have such a fine-tuned and representative map of the cycling reality.

Source: Company Website

September 18: Join the October edition of the UAB's virtual fair for Master's Degrees, Graduate Courses and PhD Programmes

Are you looking into master's degrees and graduate courses to continue your training, specialise or reorient your professional career? Have you finished a master's degree and want to continue your academic career with a PhD? Would you like to meet and speak with the coordinator(s) of the programme that interests you? The UAB's Virtual Fair for Master's Degrees, Graduate Courses and PhD Programmes celebrates a new edition so that you can find the answers to all those questions and more. We invite you to check the complete list of sessions and register for all those that are of interest to you.

From Monday 6 to Friday 10 October 2025: five days in a row to be able to receive information about a wide range of official master's degrees, UAB-specific master's degrees, graduate courses and PhD programmes in all areas of knowledge. Around 150 information sessions, each focused on a specific study programme. The sessions consist of a short introduction made by the coordinator(s) of the study programme and then a question and answer session to clear up any doubts you may have.

Source: Company Website

September 17: Twelve UAB projects selected to study and improve emotional wellbeing at universities

Twelve UAB research projects have been selected by AGAUR in a second call for the development of projects with social impacts. The projects must take on challenges related to mental health and emotional wellbeing at universities and other entities of the research and innovation system.

The selected projects cover disciplines such as clinical and health psychology, veterinary medicine, physics, nursing, social psychology, and anthropology, and will address different subjects of study. The aim is to obtain data and provide solutions for the emotional wellbeing of all members of the university community, which in turn can be extrapolated and sustained over time. The total amount obtained to conduct these studies is EUR220,000.

All selected studies will be carried out in coordination between the research groups involved, with the collaboration of the UAB's CORE in Mental Health network and the Equality and Diversity Service. The main project will be carried out by the Equality and Diversity Service, under the title "Recursos per a la promocio del benestar emocional i l'autocura per a la comunitat de la UAB: sensibilitzacio, punts blaus i grups d'ajuda mutua" [Resources for promoting emotional wellbeing and self-care for the UAB community: awareness-raising, blue points, and mutual support groups].

September 17: Autonomous University of Barcelona One more person from Palestine benefits from the #UABRefugi grants

A PhD student from Palestine will join the UAB in the 2025/26 academic year thanks to the #UABRefugi grants. The grants represent a comprehensive support model for refugees and now has been reinforced with a special fund to assist university students currently suffering from the armed conflict and genocide being committed by the Israeli state against the Palestinian population. A total of five people have already benefited from this aid.

The UAB programme is a comprehensive support model since the grants cover not only academic expenses, but also other costs related to materials and transport. The UAB also provides support to refugees, such as in the case of the new PhD student arriving from Palestine and his family, in terms of housing, either by reserving places at the Vila Universitaria or by working in coordination with the municipalities surrounding the campus. In addition, the UAB will launch a crowdfunding campaign among the university community to obtain new resources to support extra-academic needs such as legal advice, document translation, etc.

Source: Company Website

September 17: The UAB to hold European Research Night with a full informative activities session

On Friday 26 September the UAB will celebrate European Research Night with a day full of informative activities. The aim is to bring research, innovation, and their protagonists closer to audiences of all ages in a simple and fun way. Starting at 5:00 p.m., the Universitat Autonoma de Barcelona will host a research fair featuring workshops and exhibitions, games, and mini-lectures with researchers from the university and research institutes from the UAB Sphere.

The event is held each year on the last Friday of September in more than 300 cities in 30 European countries simultaneously. During the week of 22 to 26 September, more than 200 activities will be offered in Catalonia, free of charge and for all audiences, including talks, workshops, experiments, shows, and games, with the participation of researchers from more than 50 scientific institutions.

Source: Company Website

September 17: Autonomous University of Barcelona La Comunitaria to mark the start of the new academic year once again

On Tuesday 30 September, The Community returns for a new fall edition, from 12:00 noon to 4:00 p.m. The Bellaterra campus will host activities, shows, experiences, and much more. The event is an opportunity to get to know the UAB's network of associations, learn, and enjoy a unique day.

The opening speech, in the Placa del Coneixement, will kick off the 2025 fall edition of La Comunitaria. And once the day begins, attendees will be able to enjoy the entites' fair which offers a wide range of activities organised by the different groups, student councils, and services that form part of the University and enrich the UAB.

In addition, Placa del Coneixement will host various shows and performances, such as the traditional human towers by the Ganapies and sardana dancing by the Agrupacio Sardanista de Cerdanyola del Valles. It should be noted that this year's event coincides with the 25th anniversary of the UAB Solidarity Foundation (FAS), with activities to commemorate the anniversary.

September 04: Autonomous University of Barcelona Margarita Leon, new director of the Institute of Government and Public Policies

Professor Leon's appointment took place at the IGOP Council meeting on 4 July. The new director expressed her desire to lead the Institute by working closely with the people who make up the organisation and adopting a horizontal approach, sharing decisions with the entire team.

Margarita Leon holds a PhD from the London School of Economics (2000). Before joining the UAB, where she is a professor of political science, she was a lecturer in European social policy at the University of Kent (2004-2010). She was a Marie Curie postdoctoral researcher at the European University Institute in Florence (2001-2003) and a Ramon y Cajal researcher at the IGOP (2010-2015). She was also visiting professor at the University of California, Berkeley (2018), on a Fulbright scholarship and at the University of Oxford (2025). Her main areas of research are comparative social policy and welfare state reform. Professor Leon has published in numerous international books and scientific journals. Her most recent popular science book is El arte de pactar. Estado de bienestar, desigualdad y acuerdo social (Los libros de la Catarata, 2023). In 2018, she was awarded the ICREA Academia prize for excellence in research.

urn:contentItem:6GRR-0FX3-RRXG-51MF-00000-00Firefighters honoured for Black Summer bravery2025-09-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisNews5Firefighters honoured for Black Summer braverySophie Else

For 98 dark days, North East Victoria faced a fiery nightmare.

The 2019-2020 Black Summer bushfires tore through more than 1.5 million hectares of land, threatening communities, wildlife, and the very landscape itself.

More than 170 current and former staff from Forest Fire Management Victoria's Upper Murray and Ovens fire districts were honoured with a national emergency medal at a ceremony in Wodonga last Friday.

Hume deputy chief fire officer Aaron Kennedy said the courage from the emergency crews was "truly admirable".

"Many medal recipients continue to work in forest and fire management, helping to mitigate the impacts of bushfires on the community and environment," Mr Kennedy said.

The National Emergency Medal forms part of Australia's honours and awards system and recognises significant or sustained service in response to nationally significant emergencies.

Fourteen FFMVic staff were also awarded National Medals, which recognise long and distinguished service to organisations that protect life and property.

Of these, eight staff received the medal for 15 years of service, and six staff received clasps for additional decades of service.

" The Black Summer bushfires had a significant and lasting impact on many local communities, our staff, and the broader emergency management sector," Mr Kennedy said.

urn:contentItem:6H32-18F3-RSBY-50NS-00000-00Fuel reduction burns halved, as fire services tax doubled2025-10-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisFuel reduction burns halved, as fire services tax doubled

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Peter Hunt and David Johnston

Years' of neglect have left Victorians at risk, in what is shaping up to be one of the worst fire seasons in more than a decade.

A lack of resources has meant a steady decline in fuel reduction burns, which state government records show have slumped from about 200,000ha annually, when Labor came to power in late 2014, to about 100,000ha in recent years.

That decline comes despite the Allan government raking in an extra $540m in fire services tax this financial year.

Howitt Society president Peter Flinn said fuel reduction burns now amounted to little more than 1 per cent of Victoria's public land each year, "just one fifth of the minimum recommended per annum by the royal commission into the horrendous 2009 Black Saturday fires, which claimed 173 lives".

"We are frequently told by FFMV (Forest Fire Management Victoria) they would like to do more in terms of fuel management, but are constrained by a shortage of funds and/or manpower, objections from some sections of the community, and that climate change is "narrowing the windows" for suitable weather conditions," he said.

The government has admitted FFMV funding has fallen from $441.3m 2024-25 to $400.6m this financial year, but stated it was the result of specific project funding for emergency management reforms coming to an end.

However Mr Flinn said the lack of resources meant fuel reduction burns that FFMVic promised to undertake in the Southern Grampians this spring had not occurred, as thousands of tonnes of fuel built up in the canopy and the forest floor.

Further east FFMVic has cleared windblown trees from 1100ha of the 44,700ha Wombat-Lerderderg Forest, but has admitted there are large areas where thousands of logs remain lying on the forest floor from 2021 storms.

Bush User Groups United representative Stephen Smitham said the situation could get a lot

worse, once the government locked up 75,000ha of the forest in new parks and reserves, under legislation before Parliament's Upper House this week.

"I'd already be worried about going into the forest if I was a CFA volunteer," Mr Smitham said. "But if they lock it up, ban firewood collection and tracks aren't maintained it will get worse."

A 2024 University of Melbourne study, titled Throwing fuel on the fire, found hard hit windblown sites in the Wombat Forest had 300 tonnes per hectare of coarse fuels - fallen branches and logs - compared to 20t/ha in undamaged forest, which would result in "a 17-fold increase in total heat output".

FFMVic acting chief Scott Turner said: "The most recent seasonal outlook showed drying conditions for the west and southwest of the state, including the Grampians region and Wombat State Forest.

"When a bushfire starts, we are ready to respond through aggressive first attack to keep fires small."

Bureau of Meteorology maps show East Gippsland soil moisture down to a depth of 1m is very much below average, a fact that CFA South East region deputy chief officer Trevor Owen said was "not being appreciated".

Agronomist and Bindi farmer Eddy Mauger said Gippsland's fuel loads were "atrocious because there has been no backburning done this year.

"There is serious, serious scope for a bushfire season up here. If it gets into that regrowth from the 2019-20 fires on the road between Ensay and Bruthen it would go off like a nuclear bomb."

As FFMVic struggles to reduce fuel loads the Allan government has almost doubled fire service taxes on Victorian households and businesses, from $839m in 2023-24 to $1.54bn this financial year, with another hike to $1.8bn in 2026-27.

Premier Jacinta Allan and her Treasurer Jaclyn Symes have repeatedly stated "every dollar" of the emergency services volunteer tax would be used to fund emergency services, but have repeatedly refused to detail how much extra is going to FFMVic and the CFA in 2025-26.

When asked to provide details of the CFA's 2025-26 budget, Treasurer Symes office simply stated details would be released in the agency's annual report, which is unlikely to be released until after next year's November 28 state election.

Meanwhile, Victorians have been left in the dark on just how much fuel has built up in forests that cover a third of the state.

In 2020 the government stopped publishing fuel load maps for fear they could be used by arsonists, an argument the nation's leading bushfire scientists branded "ludicrous" and "a load of rubbish".

Since then the government has simply reported on statewide and regional fuel-driven bushfire risk reduction targets.

The government has set at a statewide target that equates to reducing the loss of life and property to 70 per cent of what would have occurred if no planned burning or major fires had occurred (100 per cent).

But even then access to the latest 2024-25 risk report has been delayed until December.

The most recent publicly available report for 2023-24 showed the bushfire risk at a regional level had reached 92 per cent in Melbourne's foothills, the Dandenongs and Mornington Peninsula, worse than in the lead-up to the 2009 Black Saturday fires.

When asked to supply the 2024-25 risk reports FFMVic stated they would not be released until December.

urn:contentItem:6H1H-FV73-RY93-P54C-00000-00Climate facts burn holes in bushfire claims2025-10-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisLETTERSPg. 45Climate facts burn holes in bushfire claims

Peter Flinn, president of the Howitt Society, downplays the role of climate change in bushfire severity, instead promoting fuel reduction and fire breaks.

In his letter 'Burning topic' (TWT, Oct 15), he claims: "While our climate is becoming warmer and drier, it's not this that's making fires more intense or harder to control".

This view conflicts with former Fire & Rescue NSW commissioner Greg Mullins, who claims: "Hotter temperatures and drier conditions, driven by climate change, are the root cause of these fires. It is a dangerous distraction to suggest otherwise." The 2020 bushfire royal commission also found that fuel reduction "may have no appreciable effect under extreme conditions".

Ironically, a paper on the Howitt Society's own website admits that "fuel breaks are unlikely to passively stop most fires, particularly during extreme weather", warning such beliefs create a false sense of security.

The extensive Joint Fuel Management Program in the Grampians before the 135,000ha fire in 2024-25, for example, was clearly ineffective. Research by Curtin University's Phil Zylstra and others shows old forests are three times less flammable than recently burned ones.

It's time the Howitt Society caught up with this research.

Julia Croatto, Kew Bureau blues The news item 'Forecasts flop â€¦ again' (TWT, Oct 8) made interesting reading, about the Bureau of Meteorology and its ongoing poor track record of weather forecasting.

The news report stated that of the last seven, three-month weather predictions produced this year by the BOM for Victoria, six were inaccurate.

It is not surprising that many farmers are now inclined to ignore its weather forecasts. The BOM is taxpayer funded and it receives funding of well over $300m a year. It is just not good enough.

If the BOM cannot make fairly accurate forecasts, it should be honest and state that it is incapable of doing so. And then stop making future long-term predictions until it can get it right.

I do wonder what methodology the BOM presently uses to forecast the weather? Dennis Walker, North Melbourne Breaking point CFA volunteers have been the backbone of Victoria's fire response for generations - thousands of trained men and women who drop everything to protect lives and property, often in the worst conditions imaginable.

But that backbone is now being tested to breaking point.

Funding shortfalls are leaving many brigades without the basic tools they need. More than 230 tankers are over 31 years old, posing real safety risks to the volunteers who operate them. These outdated trucks lack modern protection and reliability, putting lives on the line every fire season.

Incredibly, some CFA volunteers are now being taxed, effectively being charged to volunteer. That's not only unfair, it's disrespectful.

At the same time, operational volunteer numbers are declining. Morale is falling. Volunteers are tired of being overworked, under-resourced, and overlooked by a system that relies on their generosity while offering little in return.

The situation is made worse by Forest Fire Management Victoria's withdrawal of key firefighting vehicles, including G-Wagons and Unimogs, due to mechanical issues.

Now, some brigades are warning they may withdraw from fighting fires on public land altogether unless real support is delivered.

This is not a threat - it's a warning. The Victorian government must act now. Leigh Harry, Secretary/treasurer, CFA Volunteers Group Uneven flow This National Water Week (October 20-26) is the ideal time to start a broad discussion on the future water and food security needs of Australia.

To this point, governments do not appear to have grasped the connection between the two, and as a result our future is heading towards an increasing reliance on imported foods, and paying more for food at the supermarket.

At present, food production is threatened by government policies based on poor modelling and prioritising unrealistic end-of-system flow targets.

As a result, our current water management prioritises high levels of water storage, which is exacerbating flood risk, and unnatural flows down iconic rivers like the Murray are damaging riverbanks and, to the increasing concern of scientists, providing ideal breeding conditions for European carp, which, likewise, are damaging rivers and tributaries. In reality, we are hurting the very environment that governments claim they are trying to protect.

Shelley Scoullar, Albury, NSW

urn:contentItem:6GR9-1W03-RRXB-V0RC-00000-00Through smoke they stood: Firefighters honoured for Black Summer bravery2025-09-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisThrough smoke they stood: Firefighters honoured for Black Summer braverySophie Else

More than 170 staff members were awarded prestigious honours.

For 98 dark days, North East Victoria faced a fiery nightmare.

The 2019-2020 Black Summer bushfires tore through more than 1.5 million hectares of land, threatening communities, wildlife, and the very landscape itself.

On Friday, 12 September, more than 170 current and former staff from Forest Fire Management Victoria's Upper Murray and Ovens Fire Districts were honoured with a national emergency medal at a ceremony in Wodonga.

Hume deputy chief fire officer Aaron Kennedy said the courage from the emergency crews was "truly admirable".

"Many medal recipients continue to work in forest and fire management, helping to mitigate the impacts of bushfires on the community and environment," Mr Kennedy said.

The National Emergency Medal forms part of Australia's Honours and Awards system and recognises significant or sustained service in response to nationally significant emergencies.

Fourteen FFMVic staff were also awarded National Medals, which recognise long and distinguished service to organisations that protect life and property.

Of these, eight staff received the medal for 15 years of service, and six staff received clasps for additional decades of service.

" The Black Summer bushfires had a significant and lasting impact on many local communities, our staff, and the broader emergency management sector, Mr Kennedy said.

Medal recipients from the Ovens Fire District are recognised for their bravery and service during the Black Summer bushfires. Picture supplied

Medal recipients from the Ovens Fire District are recognised for their bravery and service during the Black Summer bushfires. Picture supplied

urn:contentItem:6H3N-5N53-S7FP-X519-00000-00Barking mad tax plan2025-11-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisCOLUMNISTPg. 21Barking mad tax planSteve Price

Victoria's dogs and cats will become the latest victims of a desperate grab for cash from the broke state Labor government.

An estimated 3.6 million domestic pets registered in Victoria at the 2023 Census are fresh tax targets.

It's almost laughable that it has come to this but, as the Herald Sun reported last weekend, state government fees to register cats and dogs will double in July next year raking in an estimated $10m in extra tax revenue.

The topped-up dog and cat tax will headline a raft of increased taxes and charges due to smash already over-taxed Victorian's during the next 12 months.

Incredibly the pet registration increases passed parliament a week ago with local councils again being asked to be tax collectors for the Jacinta Allan government just as they are now collecting the hated Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund.

Your dog and cat rego will jump from a current $4.51 to $9 that's double with, for some reason, a discounted greyhound tax $3.50 to $7, also doubling the fee.

Surely, it's time for Victorian councils to tell Spring St that if they want to tax family pets and crush homeowners and businesses with the cutely named Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund they should collect it themselves.

Do you're own dirty work!

Sadly - but predictably - dogs and cats though, are only the start of a fresh round of increasingly desperate tax grabs as the state's net debt heads to $187bn by 2028.

Bean counters inside state Treasury have obviously been tasked with targeting everything from pets to carparks, rubbish tipping fees and the golden goose of on-going taxes and fees, the road tolls paid to companies like Transurban for building the roads.

Just this week there was an attempt to generate public excitement about opening minor parts of the West Gate Tunnel project which is three years late and expected to cost almost $10bn - or double its original estimate.

There are even plans, can you believe it; to have something called the West Gate Tunnel Discovery Day on November 16, urging the community to go on an 8km run or 2.5 km walk through parts of the new tunnel.

You'd have to ask yourself who exactly might want to do that. Certainly not the various community groups around parts of Yarraville and inner suburbs angry that this late, expensive project, will increase heavy vehicle traffic in their suburbs.

What the usual bunch of government ministers and the nodding heads behind them were less likely to be talking about this week were the new "congestion taxes" attached to this new piece of Victoria's Big Build.

Commuters from the western suburbs of Melbourne will get to use the shiny new road but at a cost if they want to be on the road between the hours of 7-9am Monday to Friday.

The congestion tax as far as I can work out applies to exit ramps off the extended West Gate Freeway during the morning peak at Footscray Rd, Dynon Rd and Wurundjeri Way.

Motorcycles - which in most big cities like the Sydney Harbour Bridge go toll free - will be charged $3.27 motor vehicles $6.54 and light vehicles including vans and dual-cab tradies Utes $10.47.

Transurban will toll trucks an eye watering $19.78 a day to use the upgraded West Gate Freeway, the tunnel, new Hyde St ramps and even the existing bridge when travelling between 6am and 8pm and $13.19 overnight.

Of course, that freight cost will go straight on to the price of the goods you buy.

Outside the congestion taxes - words the government hates to hear - the new West Gate Tunnel will cost a motorbike rider $2.05 a trip, a car $4.09 and a light vehicle $6.54.

The old West Gate Bridge will still be toll free so guess where the bulk of the traffic will travel when you consider a tradie from the west would have to cough up over $35 a week in tolls.

The state government will argue it's the road operator Transurban charging the tolls not them, but without the right to toll motorists the project would never have been built and its government policy to introduce a timed congestion levy.

Then of course from July this year we have been paying the ESVF also known as the Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund.

It's a compulsory charge again collected by local councils - reluctantly - frozen for a year on primary producers after major protests.

The ESVF is paid by residential, commercial, industrial and primary property owners calculated on a cent per $1000 of improved value.

This on top of your existing council rates.

Complicated - as the government wants it to be - the increases year on year are obvious.

Residential has gone from 8.7 cents per $1,000 of capital improved value to 136 cents, commercial from 66.4 to 275, industrial 81.1 to 275 and primary will eventually go from 28.7 to 275.

Spring Street says the increased levy will fund fire services, the SES, Triple Zero and Forest Fire Management.

We will see if that really happens.

Then we have another congestion levy this time put on car park spaces across two zones that will from January 1 next year explode in cost. The levies are paid by car park owners private or public per parking spot annually.

Category one annual fees are currently $1750 per parking spot. Next year that same bit of bitumen, with no improvement, will cost $3030. Category two goes from $1240 to $2150 a 73 per cent increase across two categories.

Add to that list the real estate-destroying land tax increases lumped on us by former Treasurer Tim Pallas, who was central to the financial mess we are in before walking away pension in hand.

We even discovered this week that failure to pay your crippling land tax bill on say an investment property or a business premises, under state land tax laws, allows Jacinta and her mates to extract the money from your bank if you have a mortgage on the property and have the sum added to your loan.

That's outrageous!

Paying taxes to park your car, walk your dog or buy a cat, drive on a toll road, own a house or start a business all the while watching massive government waste on late over budget big build projects.

It's the price we are all paying for government incompetence run by an outfit who have never risked their own money on anything.

It's no wonder the Hume Highway is jammed with fed-up business owners and disillusioned Victorians heading north.

urn:contentItem:6GTV-PC53-RRW5-419K-00000-00Blaze burns 100 acres of farmland2025-09-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisNews5Blaze burns 100 acres of farmlandJessica Howard

A man lit the blaze during a fire danger period.

A Merino man says he failed to properly extinguish a fire that spread out of control and scorched more than 100 acres of farmland he was renting.

Andrew Malcom Alderton , 66, lit the fire to burn thistles during Glenelg Shire Council's fire danger period.

He pleaded guilty in Hamilton Magistrates' Court on Wednesday to lighting a fire in the open air without authorisation.

The court heard CFA called police to a scrub fire on Portland-Casterton Road about 1pm on April 10.

Police members were informed by the CFA incident controller the fire had started as a result of Alderton lighting a fire on the property.

There were about 15 CFA and Forest Fire Management trucks called to contain the blaze, which burned about 100 acres of grass, trees and fencing.

Lawyer Jessica Dowdy said her client had been living in a private rental at the Merino farming property.

She said Alderton lit the "very small" fire near a chook yard in order to get rid of thistles and other gardening waste.

Ms Dowdy said the man did not come from a farming background and thought it was OK given there was no strong breeze or other significant weather issues.

She said the man admitted he did not do any checks of the CFA website, but noted the fire season had been extended at the time.

Within less than five minutes of lighting the fire, a driver pulled over and warned him of the fire danger period, Ms Dowdy said.

She said her client immediately extinguished the fire "to the best of his knowledge" with sand. Alderton left the property, and it is believed the fire reignited and quickly spread to nearby grass, which became fully inflamed.

Ms Dowdy said when Alderton returned, he immediately helped CFA in their firefighting efforts.

"My client accepts full responsibility for his actions," she said.

"He instructs me he is remorseful. He has apologised personally to the firefighters that he's had interactions with that he knew from fighting the fire alongside them. He has also personally apologised to the farmer and assisted him with repairing all the fences involved."

Ms Dowdy said Alderton had an "urgent and imminent major surgery" that was potentially life-threatening, and urged the court to consider a good behaviour bond.

Magistrate Kimberley Swadesir said the danger Alderton's actions caused was obvious and led to multiple CFA trucks attending.

"It's a farmer's worst nightmare for a fire to get away from them," she said. "You clearly didn't take enough steps to ensure the fire was out. I understand that from this incident, you've changed your practices and one would hope that you're only starting fires in appropriate areas in an incinerator, or example, as opposed to just in the open air."

Alderton was convicted, placed on a six-month good behaviour bond and ordered to donate $2000 to the CFA.

The Standard recently revealed there were 89 escaped burn-offs across the region in the year to September 17 .

urn:contentItem:6GRM-PM93-RS73-H0T4-00000-00Protest fired up over levy2025-09-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Protest fired up over levyAmelia Swan Euan Kennedy

CFA volunteers have branded the Labor government's emergency services levy an "outright lie" as they continue to push for the tax to be scrapped.

Crews of volunteers from across the state rolled into Bendigo on Sunday, in a major demonstration against the tax they say does not fund the very services it was introduced to support.

"It's an outright lie to cover mismanagement of our money," CFA Volunteers Group vice president Brad Marson told the Herald Sun.

"They just raise it and raise it and raise it and it doesn't go to the emergency services." Mr Marson said community frustration was growing as more people began to understand the impact of the levy, warning the impacts extend beyond just the CFA.

"We're doing this and we'll keep doing this around Victoria, as more Victorians see what's going on they'll need to scrap the tax," he said.

"Every Victorian will pay it, no matter where you are. This isn't a one off, it's only going to keep getting worse, they've put the levy up 100 per cent last year.

"Renters are going to feel it, property owners and landlords are going to pass it on." Mr Marson said the community remains at the heart of the movement, with Sunday's strong turnout and local support sending a message the government can't ignore.

"These are CFA volunteers - when someone needs help across the state, we answer. We go not for the money, but because we want to help people," he said.

"There's been a great public response, coming through Bendigo we've had cars tooting, people waving, anyone and everyone, my rough count is 2000 people here and there'd be over 100 CFA tankers.

"The momentum we have here they can't ignore." Environment Minister Steve Dimopoulos backed the levy saying the Allan government funds the fire services "better than any government in Victoria's history".

"We have a track record in terms of supporting firefighters, their fleet and their resources," he said.

"They work too hard not to be able to have what they need in perpetuity, and that's what this does." "As the premier made very clear, the impacts of climate change, changing weather patterns and natural disasters impact all Victorians but more so regional Victorians. "We've made a decision to make sure that the funding for these major services, CFA, SES, and Forest Fire Management Victoria, is secured into the long term."

urn:contentItem:6GRH-KMX3-RSS1-4330-00000-00'Outright lie': CFA volunteers blast Labor's emergency services tax2025-09-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexis'Outright lie': CFA volunteers blast Labor's emergency services tax

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Amelia Swan and Euan Kennedy

CFA volunteers have branded the Labor government's emergency services levy an "outright lie" as they continue to push for the tax to be scrapped.

Crews of volunteers from across the state rolled into Bendigo on Sunday, in a major demonstration against the tax they say does not fund the very services it was introduced to support.

"It's an outright lie to cover mismanagement of our money," CFA Volunteers Group Vice President Brad Marson told the Herald Sun.

"They just raise it and raise it and raise it and it doesn't go to the emergency services."

Mr Marson said community frustration was growing as more people began to understand the impact of the levy, warning the impacts extend beyond just the CFA.

"We're doing this and we'll keep doing this around Victoria, as more Victorians see what's going on they'll need to scrap the tax," he said.

"Every Victorian will pay it, no matter where you are. This isn't a one off, it's only going to keep getting worse, they've put the levy up 100 per cent last year.

"Renters are going to feel it, property owners and landlords are going to pass it on.''

Mr Marson said the community remains at the heart of the movement, with Sunday's strong turnout and local support sending a message the government can't ignore.

"These are CFA volunteers - when someone needs help across the state, we answer. We go not for the money, but because we want to help people," he said.

"There's been a really great public response, coming through Bendigo we've had cars tooting, people waving, anyone and everyone, my rough count is 2000 people here and there'd be over 100 CFA tankers.

"The momentum we have here they can't ignore."

Environment Minister Steve Dimopoulos backed the levy saying the Allan government funds the fire services "better than any government in Victoria's history."

"We have a track record in terms of supporting firefighters, their fleet and their resources," he said.

"They work too hard not to be able to have what they need in perpetuity, and that's what this does."

"As the premier made very clear, the impacts of climate change, changing weather patterns and natural disasters impact all Victorians but more so regional Victorians.

"We've made a decision as a government to make sure that the funding for these major services, CFA, SES, and Forest Fire Management Victoria, is secured into the long term.

"Given the impacts of drought this year, we've made a bunch of exemptions in relation to active CFA and SES volunteers, in relation to their primary place of residence or their farm."

urn:contentItem:6H04-PX93-RVJ5-M1CH-00000-00Trump's tariff threat could pop bubble2025-10-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisCOMPANIES AND MARKETSPg. 27Trump's tariff threat could pop bubbleCLOSING BELLJames Thomson

Last week, the US exchange-traded fund designer Tuttle Capital Management filed 60 new single stock ETFs with three times leverage for regulatory approval.

The idea behind these leveraged single-stock ETFs is simple. By using derivatives, a buyer gets access to a vehicle that magnifies the moves in the share price of a particular company. Buy an Oracle ETF with two times leverage and a 5 per cent rise in the ordinary shares delivers a 10 per cent gain.

But the catch is obvious: if the stock falls by 5 per cent, the ETF with three times leverage plunges 15 per cent.

The proliferation of these leveraged ETFs has been a big consequence of the equity market rally that has continued for three years. But after the sudden fall in US equity markets on Friday after US President Donald Trump threatened 100 per cent tariffs on China, these leveraged vehicles are a source of real risk.

Nick Ferres, chief investment officer at Singapore-based macro fund Vantage Point Asset Management, has a simple rule: if you want to know where the risk is, follow the leverage.

"The impulsive correction in the US markets on Friday was the start of a probable unwind in extreme leverage, crowded positions, and consensus beliefs," Ferres says.

"The announcement on tariffs was simply the lightning strike that sparked the forest fire. The fuel was the liquidity and levered positions in ETFs and single stock positions in the major technology companies."

Clearly, the artificial intelligence boom is based on something very real, but the run-up in valuations has reached a level of euphoria in the past few months. There's the money piling into AI start-ups. There's the circular deals giants of the sector (led by OpenAI and Nvidia) are doing every other day. And if that's not enough, there are repeated warnings from those at the centre of the boom, including OpenAI boss Sam Altman and Amazon founder Jeff Bezos, that this is actually a bubble.

Ferres says the more than $US10 billion ($15.3 billion) collapse of previously unknown car parts group First Brands is significant.

As this column explained on Friday, investment bank Jefferies, which was First Brands' banker for a decade, is at the centre of the disaster. Its 4 per cent plunge in ordinary trade on Friday took the fall in its share price in three weeks to 28 per cent. A story suggesting fresh redemptions were possible from a Jefferies-controlled fund then saw the stock shed another 6.5 per cent in after hours trade.

But the fallout is also hitting private credit and private equity. First Brands' debt was held by several publicly listed private debt vehicles called business development companies (BDCs) and the whole sector continues to tank.

Meanwhile, private capital giants including Blackstone, KKR, Ares Management and Apollo Global Management fell sharply again on Friday and are down almost 20 per cent in three weeks.

Ferres says while the sector's recent underperformance could have been a warning signal to investors about risk assets, allegations of fraud at First Brands is the cherry on top of the bearish sandwich.

"Fraud is often uncovered at the end of a boom bust episode," he says.

First Brands' losses are not large enough to cause a systemic shock. But the psychological impact - if this is happening at one company, could it be happening across the private credit sector? - shouldn't be underestimated.

There are plenty of predictions about what might happen on Monday as equity markets start opening. Will we see investors shrug this off, bet on Trump winding back his tariff threats and buy the dip yet again? That tactic has worked in the past three years and investors learnt earlier this year there is a limit to the amount of sharemarket pain Trump is willing to endure.

Or are we seeing a bout of real panic? We are in a different place to April, with positioning and valuations much more extreme than they were. Investors have tried to reap big gains that always accompany bubbly periods by betting they could get out before the popping really began. Is this that moment?

So far, Trump hasn't said anything else on the tariff threat. It's clearly possible that we get a social media post announcing he and Chinese President Xi Jinping have agreed to talk things over, but investors can't bank on it.

Cryptocurrency markets, abuzz with talk that an investor managed to action a $US190 million short trade minutes before Trump announced the latest tariff threat, have been falling all weekend. This could be a taste of what lies ahead for risk assets if Trump doesn't back down.

Ferres says there are two questions investors should ask themselves. The first is: where is the leverage? Leverage is part of equity market strategies that have proliferated in the past few years and distribution is ramping up.

The second is: am I being compensated for risk? The answer is obvious given risk premiums in equities are historically elevated and spreads in publicly traded credit are extremely narrow.

Stocks have long been priced for perfection, so now the task is to assess what risks are being discounted. Think of Nvidia: have investors priced in a jump in the cost of components from China?

Are US stocks pricing in elevated inflation, spurred by Chinese tariffs, that could either push interest rates higher or prevent them from falling like the market expects? What about the risks for stocks in markets like Australia - will our miners get caught up in this mess or do they benefit?

For his part, Ferres is cautious. "Following the strong rally in risk assets over the past few months, the challenging policy outlook and elevated valuations mean the odds of a meaningful correction have increased," Ferres says.

Strap in for an eventful few days.

urn:contentItem:6H01-NMS3-RSXW-D0MJ-00000-00How Trump's tariff threat could pop the market bubble2025-10-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisHow Trump's tariff threat could pop the market bubbleJames Thomson

The US president's latest tariff threat, and the stock sell-off it has already caused, will prompt investors to reassess risks they've been happy to ignore for months.

Last week, the US exchange-traded fund designer Tuttle Capital Management filed 60 new single stock ETFs with three times leverage for regulatory approval.

The idea behind these leveraged single-stock ETFs is simple. By using derivatives, a buyer gets access to a vehicle that magnifies the moves in the share price of a particular company. Buy an Oracle ETF with two times leverage and a 5 per cent rise in the ordinary shares delivers a 10 per cent gain.

Link to Image

David Rowe

But the catch is obvious: if the stock falls by 5 per cent, the ETF with three times leverage plunges 15 per cent.

The proliferation of these leveraged ETFs has been a big consequence of the equity market rally that has continued for three years. But after the sudden fall in US equity markets on Friday after US President Donald Trump threatened 100 per cent tariffs on China, these leveraged vehicles are a source of real risk.

Nick Ferres, chief investment officer at Singapore-based macro fund Vantage Point Asset Management, has a simple rule: if you want to know where the risk is, follow the leverage.

"The impulsive correction in the US markets on Friday was the start of a probable unwind in extreme leverage, crowded positions, and consensus beliefs," Ferres says.

"The announcement on tariffs was simply the lightning strike that sparked the forest fire. The fuel was the liquidity and levered positions in ETFs and single stock positions in the major technology companies."

Clearly, the artificial intelligence boom is based on something very real, but the run-up in valuations has reached a level of euphoria in the past few months. There's the money piling into AI start-ups. There's the circular deals giants of the sector (led by OpenAI and Nvidia) are doing every other day. And if that's not enough, there are repeated warnings from those at the centre of the boom, including OpenAI boss Sam Altman and Amazon founder Jeff Bezos, that this is actually a bubble.

Ferres says the more than $US10 billion ($15.3 billion) collapse of previously unknown car parts group First Brands is significant.

As this column explained on Friday, investment bank Jefferies, which was First Brands' banker for a decade, is at the centre of the disaster. Its 4 per cent plunge in ordinary trade on Friday took the fall in its share price in three weeks to 28 per cent. A story suggesting fresh redemptions were possible from a Jefferies-controlled fund then saw the stock shed another 6.5 per cent in after hours trade.

But the fallout is also hitting private credit and private equity. First Brands' debt was held by several publicly listed private debt vehicles called business development companies (BDCs) and the whole sector continues to tank.

Meanwhile, private capital giants including Blackstone, KKR, Ares Management and Apollo Global Management fell sharply again on Friday and are down almost 20 per cent in three weeks.

Ferres says while the sector's recent underperformance could have been a warning signal to investors about risk assets, allegations of fraud at First Brands is the cherry on top of the bearish sandwich.

"Fraud is often uncovered at the end of a boom bust episode," he says.

First Brand's losses are not large enough to cause a systemic shock. But the psychological impact - if this is happening at one company, could it be happening across the private credit sector? - shouldn't be underestimated.

There are plenty of predictions about what might happen on Monday as equity markets start opening across the world.

Will we see investors shrug this off, bet on Trump winding back his tariff threats and buy the dip yet again? That tactic has worked in the past three years and investors learnt earlier this year there is a limit to the amount of sharemarket pain Trump is willing to endure.

Or are we seeing a bout of real panic? We are in a different place to April, with positioning and valuations much more extreme than they were. Investors have tried to reap big gains that always accompany bubbly periods by betting they could get out before the popping really began. Is this that moment?

So far, Trump hasn't said anything else on the tariff threat. It's clearly possible that we get a social media post announcing he and Chinese President Xi Jinping have agreed to talk things over, but investors can't bank on it.

Cryptocurrency markets, abuzz with talk that an investor managed to action a $US190 million short trade minutes before Trump announced the latest tariff threat, have been falling all weekend. This could be a taste of what lies ahead for risk assets if Trump doesn't back down.

Ferres says there are two questions investors should ask themselves. The first is: where is the leverage? Leverage is part of equity market strategies that have proliferated in the past few years and distribution is ramping up.

The second is: am I being compensated for risk? The answer is obvious given risk premiums in equities are historically elevated and spreads in publicly traded credit are extremely narrow.

Stocks have long been priced for perfection, so now the task is to assess what risks are being discounted. Think of Nvidia: have investors priced in a jump in the cost of components from China?

Are US stocks pricing in elevated inflation, spurred by Chinese tariffs, that could either push interest rates higher or prevent them from falling like the market expects? What about the risks for stocks in markets like Australia - will our miners get caught up in this mess or do they benefit?

For his part, Ferres is cautious. "Following the strong rally in risk assets over the past few months, the challenging policy outlook and elevated valuations mean the odds of a meaningful correction have increased," Ferres says.

Strap in for an eventful few days.

There are plenty of predictions about what might happen on Monday as equity markets start opening across the world. Will we see investors shrug this off, bet on Trump winding back his tariff threats and buy the dip yet again?

urn:contentItem:6GK1-M8M3-RRY3-92SS-00000-00Mystery surrounds fires as three vehicles go up in flames in remote forest2025-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisMystery surrounds fires as three vehicles go up in flames in remote forestBlair Thomson

Member of the public alerts police to three car fires at Stanley.

Beechworth police are investigating a bizarre incident in which three vehicles were destroyed by fire in the Stanley State Forest.

Fire crews weren't alerted to the weekend blaze, with police notified by a member of the public on Sunday morning.

Investigators believe the fires, which involved a Holden Commodore, Holden Astra, and a Toyota Echo or Yaris, occurred between 4pm on Saturday and 9am on Sunday, August 24.

The cars were so badly burned, plates and VIN numbers couldn't be deciphered.

All three vehicles were located in close proximity.

The incident occurred on Twist Creek Road at Stanley, near the intersection of Rawes Road.

"It appears they've had a bit of a joyride in the Stanley State Forest due to there being debris and skid marks in the vicinity," a Beechworth police spokesman said.

"We're seeking any information in relation to hoon driving in the area."

Firefighters weren't called to the blaze, which burnt itself out.

The incident occurred in an isolated part of the forest, near Yackandandah.

Anyone with information can call (03) 5728 1032 or 1800 333 000.

The blaze followed a fire involving a four-wheel-drive stolen from Myrtleford.

The white Toyota had been taken about 11.10pm on Thursday.

The vehicle had been spotted travelling in convoy with a Hyundai by Wodonga officers about 3.05am on Friday.

Police successfully tyre-spiked the Hyundai and seized the vehicle, but the occupants fled.

The Toyota continued into Albury and was then gutted by flames on Strauss Street at Springdale Heights.

Albury and Wodonga police are investigating.

Two Holdens and Toyota were found burnt out in the Stanley State Forest by a member of the public on Sunday, August 24. Firefighters were unaware of the fires, which appear to have burnt themselves out. Picture by Ethan Ramsay

In other news, police are investigating a fire at a Bright property, with a door to the building burnt during yesterday's blaze.

Wangaratta detectives are investigating. Anyone with information can call (03) 5723 0888 or 1800 333 000.

urn:contentItem:6GVW-H2N3-RX09-902P-00000-00Updated: September 26, 2025: The UAB's religious research group, ISOR, receives the Memorial Alex Seglers Award for their commitment to religious diversity and other recent news2025-09-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSUpdated: September 26, 2025: The UAB's religious research group, ISOR, receives the Memorial Alex Seglers Award for their commitment to religious diversity and other recent news

The Research in the Sociology of Religion (ISOR-UAB) group received the Memorial Alex Seglers Award yesterday in an event held in Sabadell for its pioneering tasks in studying religious diversity from a scientific viewpoint.

INDEX

SECTION 1 PRESS RELEASES: 2025

SECTION 2 OTHER NEWS: 2025

SECTION 1 PRESS RELEASES: 2025

September 26: Autonomous University of Barcelona: FAS celebrates its 25th anniversary at La Comunitaria

Tuesday 30 September the UAB will be holding La Comunitaria and the Fundacio Autonoma Solidaria (FAS) will be there with a very special stand to celebrate 25 years of social actions at university. From 12 noon to 4:00 p.m. the Placa del Coneixement will be the site of activities, games and spaces to chat about the programmes and people who have helped to make changes, and also benefited from these social actions.

Source: Company Website

September 26: The UAB launches a campaign to make the Republican exile visible

The Chair of the Republican Literary Exile (CEXLIR) of the Department of Spanish Studies at the UAB is organising a conference dedicated to the memory of the Republican exile of 1939, with the aim of collecting testimonials from the relatives of exiles. Based on these stories, they will produce a collective book to recover and keep alive the historical memory of those people forced to leave the country. Those interested can give their support to the initiative through the UAB crowdfunding portal.

Source: Company Website

September 22: Events Calendar: Autonomous University of Barcelona: Faculty of Arts & Humanities' exhibition brings together stories of empowerment from migrant women and girls

Two spaces at the Faculty of Arts & Humanities, PassArtdis and Sala TarotdeQuinze, will host the exhibition "Punts de fuga. Relats d'empoderament de dones i nenes d'origen migrant" until 22 November. The exhibition calls for the inclusion of migrant women and includes photographs, audio recordings, tactile elements, and objects.

Source: Company Website

September 22: Events Calendar: The UAB to host the First Artistic Heritage Campus Research Conference

On 2 October the Periodicals Room of the Humanities Library, located in the Faculty of Arts & Humanities, will host the First Artistic Heritage Campus Research Conference, a meeting aimed at strengthening ties between the academic world and museum and heritage institutions. Imatge del cartell de la I Jornada del Campus de Patrimoni Artistic de la UAB

The main goal of the conference is to promote synergies between the University and the organisations making up this network, inviting participating institutions to present their ongoing research projects and propose new lines of research related to the collections, which could be developed in the final degree projects (TFG) and final master theses (TFM) of the studies linked to the Campus.

Source: Company Website

SECTION 2 OTHER NEWS: 2025

September 26: Autonomous University of Barcelona: Global study uncovers the drivers of animal anti-predator colour strategies

Published in Science and featured on the cover of its latest issue, the research, conducted with the involvement of the UAB and the CVC, a global study highlights how ecological context and multiple factors determine whether camouflage or warning colouration provide the greatest evolutionary advantage.

Source: Company Website

September 26: Autonomous University of Barcelona: Inequality in agri-food chains: the Global South produces the food, but the Global North keeps the wealth

In the global agri-food system, most agricultural goods are produced in the Global South but value is captured by countries of the Global North through growth and control of the post farmgate sectors.

Source: Company Website

September 26: Autonomous University of Barcelona: Course for teachers working with gypsy pupils in situations of vulnerability

On 2 October, the UAB Faculty of Arts & Humanities will host the presentation of the course Realidad Educativa en la Comunidad Gitana en Exclusion, aimed at professionals and students of education and social sciences working with gypsy pupils who are in situations of vulberability. This free and mainly online course is organised by the Romano Institute for Social and Cultural Affairs, in collaboration with the UAB, and is funded by the Spanish Ministry for Social Rights, Consumption and 2020 Agenda. The course is open to 50 people and will take place from 2 October to 19 December.

Source: Company Website

September 23: Culture and wellbeing: the UAB to inaugurate its First Culture and Health Week

From 13 to 16 October, the Universitat Autonoma de Barcelona will be holding the first edition of its Culture and Health Week, an initiative that invites members to reflect on their emotional wellbeing through a variety of cultural proposals. Entrance to all activities is free.

Source: Company Website

September 23: Autonomous University of Barcelona: Marc Torrent and Aura Muntasell selected by the CaixaImpulse programme

The research projects of UAB lecturers Marc Torrent, aimed at tackling antibiotic resistance, and Aura Muntasell, aimed at developing a new cell therapy for cancer, will receive funding from the CaixaImpulse programme, which gives financial support to 31 biomedical projects from research centres, hospitals, and universities in Spain and Portugal.

Source: Company Website

September 23: Autonomous University of Barcelona: Study shows Barbary sheep do not compete with mountain goats and questions its status as an invasive species

A study by researchers from the UAB, CSIC, and UPM provides the first empirical evidence of dietary compatibility between exotic and native species in Spain. The results call into question the classification of the Barbary sheep as an invasive species.

Source: Company Website

September 22: Autonomous University of Barcelona: Flu vaccination campaign begins

From 13 October to 10 December, the UAB Healthcare Service will be running a flu vaccination campaign for the entire university community. vacunaciogrip2017

From 13 October to 10 December, the university community will be able to receive the flu vaccine administered by the UAB Healthcare Service. The vaccination campaign is available to the entire university community, especially those at high risk of complications related to the flu.

Source: Company Website

This new academic year experience the UAB in a different and more enriching manner. All of these programmes work for peace, equality, sustainability and global justice. The Fundacio Autonoma Solidaria (FAS), an association with over 25 years of experience in university social actions, presents it catalogue of volunteering proposals for this 2025/26 academic year.

September 19: Autonomous University of Barcelona First case of betanodavirus infection in a grouper confirmed in Catalonia in 2025

On 7 September a specimen of grouper (Epinephelus marginatus) was detected in waters near Barcelona with clear symptoms consistent with betanodavirus infection, also known as viral nervous necrosis (VNN). The discovery was made possible thanks to a report from a member of the Barcelona Underwater Fishing Association (APS), who sent the specimen to the Fish Pathology Diagnostic Service at the Universitat Autonoma de Barcelona (UAB). Samples of the fish were then sent to the European reference laboratory for this disease, where molecular techniques (qPCR) confirmed a very high presence of the virus in the animal's brain.

This identification, together with other reports of dead or symptomatic groupers, unequivocally confirms the spread of VNN and its presence in the coastal waters of Catalonia. For several years now, this betanodavirus has been causing outbreaks of mortality in groupers and other fish species throughout the Mediterranean, with particularly severe outbreaks in Greece, southern Italy, Spain, and recently in the Azores. In Spain, this virus had already caused outbreaks in the Balearic Islands, and a few years ago outbreaks were detected on the coast of the peninsula, with a progressive advance northwards causing very significant mortality of groupers in nature reserves such as Cabrera and Columbretes.

September 18: Autonomous University of Barcelona Horses, possible allies in forest fire prevention

The research-which included the participation of Boumort Wildland, the Miranda Foundation, the Forest Horses association, and the University of Barcelona (UB)-reveals that horses adapt their diet according to breed, environment and use. This flexibility helps them play a complementary role alongside other herbivores in sustainable fire prevention strategies, given that their grazing reduces fuel loads and maintains open landscapes. The study was co-authored by researchers from the Department of Animal and Food Science at the UAB Jordi Bartolome and Araceli Gort-Esteve.

"Until now research on extensive herding and forest fire prevention has focused mainly on sheep and goats, with some isolated studies done on breeds of rustic cattle. There have been very few studies on horses within this context, since traditionally they are classified as plant grazers that have little effect on woody vegetations", explains Ariadna Nieto-Espinet, Ramon y Cajal researcher at the UdL and zooarchaeologist. "Our work is one of the first to use empirical data to analyse their potential in forest management in the Mediterannean", she adds.

September 18: The UAB brings together leading experts in space communications in Barcelona

On 22 and 23 September, Casa Convalescencia UAB will host the Satellite Network of Experts V Seasonal School, with the participation of leading experts in satellite and space communications such as Holly Ridings from NASA and Oana Graur from ESA. Satellits

The Quantum Communication and Secure Information (Q-CSI) research group, from the Department of Telecommunications and Systems Engineering at the UAB, organises the EURASIP Satellite Network of Experts V Seasonal School, a project of the European Space Agency (ESA) within the framework of the Connectivity and Secure Communications (CSC) department, co-organised by the Institute of Space Studies of Catalonia (IEEC).

The school is aimed at early-stage researchers and industry professionals, PhD students, and postdoctoral researchers interested in exploring the latest advances in satellite and space communications. It will take place on 22 and 23 Septemeber at Casa Convalescencia UAB and is organised in conjunction with the International Conference on Satellite Systems Communications (ICSSC 2025) of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics (AIAA), which will take place from 23 to 25 September.

September 19: Autonomous University of Barcelona First case of betanodavirus infection in a grouper confirmed in Catalonia in 2025

On 7 September a specimen of grouper (Epinephelus marginatus) was detected in waters near Barcelona with clear symptoms consistent with betanodavirus infection, also known as viral nervous necrosis (VNN). The discovery was made possible thanks to a report from a member of the Barcelona Underwater Fishing Association (APS), who sent the specimen to the Fish Pathology Diagnostic Service at the Universitat Autonoma de Barcelona (UAB). Samples of the fish were then sent to the European reference laboratory for this disease, where molecular techniques (qPCR) confirmed a very high presence of the virus in the animal's brain.

This identification, together with other reports of dead or symptomatic groupers, unequivocally confirms the spread of VNN and its presence in the coastal waters of Catalonia. For several years now, this betanodavirus has been causing outbreaks of mortality in groupers and other fish species throughout the Mediterranean, with particularly severe outbreaks in Greece, southern Italy, Spain, and recently in the Azores. In Spain, this virus had already caused outbreaks in the Balearic Islands, and a few years ago outbreaks were detected on the coast of the peninsula, with a progressive advance northwards causing very significant mortality of groupers in nature reserves such as Cabrera and Columbretes.

September 19: Autonomous University of Barcelona: First case of betanodavirus infection in a grouper confirmed in Catalonia in 2025

Thanks to citizen collaboration, on 7 September a grouper with symptoms of betanodavirus infection was detected in waters near Barcelona, diagnosed by the UAB Fish Pathology Diagnostic Service. For several years, the virus has been causing outbreaks of mortality in groupers and other fish species throughout the Mediterranean. The UAB and the Institute of Marine Sciences (ICM-CSIC) have set up an alert and sample collection network to identify cases and monitor the evolution of the disease. Mero

On 7 September a specimen of grouper (Epinephelus marginatus) was detected in waters near Barcelona with clear symptoms consistent with betanodavirus infection, also known as viral nervous necrosis (VNN). The discovery was made possible thanks to a report from a member of the Barcelona Underwater Fishing Association (APS), who sent the specimen to the Fish Pathology Diagnostic Service at the Universitat Autonoma de Barcelona (UAB). Samples of the fish were then sent to the European reference laboratory for this disease, where molecular techniques (qPCR) confirmed a very high presence of the virus in the animal's brain.

Source: Company Website

September 19: More intercity buses to take you to the UAB

This year, the intercity bus routes connecting with the UAB will add almost 90 new departures. This affects the Barcelona-Cerdanyola-UAB, Sabadell-Barbera-Badia-UAB, Mataro-Argentona-UAB, Igualada-Martorell-UAB, and Montcada-Ripollet-UAB lines. These improvements are part of the Intercity Bus Emergency Plan, which receives an investment of EUR17 million. Bus a l'eix central de la UAB

On 19 September, UAB Rector Javier Lafuente was accompanied by Xavier Gabarrell, vice-rector for Campus and Sustainability, and Manel Nadal, secretary for Mobility and Infrastructure of the Government of Catalonia, at the presentation of the improvements for this 2025/26 academic year, which included almost 90 new departures of several intercity buses connecting the nearby towns with the UAB.

Source: Company Website

September 18: Autonomous University of Barcelona Horses, possible allies in forest fire prevention

The research-which included the participation of Boumort Wildland, the Miranda Foundation, the Forest Horses association, and the University of Barcelona (UB)-reveals that horses adapt their diet according to breed, environment and use. This flexibility helps them play a complementary role alongside other herbivores in sustainable fire prevention strategies, given that their grazing reduces fuel loads and maintains open landscapes. The study was co-authored by researchers from the Department of Animal and Food Science at the UAB Jordi Bartolome and Araceli Gort-Esteve.

"Until now research on extensive herding and forest fire prevention has focused mainly on sheep and goats, with some isolated studies done on breeds of rustic cattle. There have been very few studies on horses within this context, since traditionally they are classified as plant grazers that have little effect on woody vegetations", explains Ariadna Nieto-Espinet, Ramon y Cajal researcher at the UdL and zooarchaeologist. "Our work is one of the first to use empirical data to analyse their potential in forest management in the Mediterannean", she adds.

Source: Company Website

September 18: The UAB brings together leading experts in space communications in Barcelona

On 22 and 23 September, Casa Convalescencia UAB will host the Satellite Network of Experts V Seasonal School, with the participation of leading experts in satellite and space communications such as Holly Ridings from NASA and Oana Graur from ESA. Satellits

The Quantum Communication and Secure Information (Q-CSI) research group, from the Department of Telecommunications and Systems Engineering at the UAB, organises the EURASIP Satellite Network of Experts V Seasonal School, a project of the European Space Agency (ESA) within the framework of the Connectivity and Secure Communications (CSC) department, co-organised by the Institute of Space Studies of Catalonia (IEEC).

The school is aimed at early-stage researchers and industry professionals, PhD students, and postdoctoral researchers interested in exploring the latest advances in satellite and space communications. It will take place on 22 and 23 Septemeber at Casa Convalescencia UAB and is organised in conjunction with the International Conference on Satellite Systems Communications (ICSSC 2025) of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics (AIAA), which will take place from 23 to 25 September.

If you are a UAB student and want to share your experience with others, this is your chance! We are looking for 64 undergraduate and graduate students interested in explaining the different degrees and services offered at the UAB and solve any doubts future UABers may have.

We offer three different internships, one with 60 places and two more with two places each:

The first is the Promotional activities which consists in 100 hours distributed throughout the months of January and May 2026, and focusing on student participation in activities and events, such as the Education Fair, Open Days, Family Days and other activities, both on-site and online. All of the activities can be found at the #VisitTheUAB website. Students will receive a grant of 746 euros gross in total. A total of 60 placements are offered to students from all faculties and schools, to be able to explain the wide range of academic programmes available at the UAB. You must sign up through Nexus.

September 26: Autonomous University of Barcelona: FAS celebrates its 25th anniversary at La Comunitaria

Tuesday 30 September the UAB will be holding La Comunitaria and the Fundacio Autonoma Solidaria (FAS) will be there with a very special stand to celebrate 25 years of social actions at university. The Chair of the Republican Literary Exile (CEXLIR) of the Department of Spanish Studies at the UAB is organising a conference dedicated to the memory of the Republican exile of 1939, with the aim of collecting testimonials from the relatives of exiles. Based on these stories, they will produce a collective book to recover and keep alive the historical memory of those people forced to leave the country. Those interested can give their support to the initiative through the UAB crowdfunding portal.

Two spaces at the Faculty of Arts & Humanities, PassArtdis and Sala TarotdeQuinze, will host the exhibition "Punts de fuga. Relats d'empoderament de dones i nenes d'origen migrant" until 22 November. The exhibition calls for the inclusion of migrant women and includes photographs, audio recordings, tactile elements, and objects.

On 2 October the Periodicals Room of the Humanities Library, located in the Faculty of Arts & Humanities, will host the First Artistic Heritage Campus Research Conference, a meeting aimed at strengthening ties between the academic world and museum and heritage institutions. Imatge del cartell de la I Jornada del Campus de Patrimoni Artistic de la UAB

This free and mainly online course is organised by the Romano Institute for Social and Cultural Affairs, in collaboration with the UAB, and is funded by the Spanish Ministry for Social Rights, Consumption and 2020 Agenda. A study by researchers from the UAB, CSIC, and UPM provides the first empirical evidence of dietary compatibility between exotic and native species in Spain. The results call into question the classification of the Barbary sheep as an invasive species.

September 19: Autonomous University of Barcelona First case of betanodavirus infection in a grouper confirmed in Catalonia in 2025

On 7 September a specimen of grouper (Epinephelus marginatus) was detected in waters near Barcelona with clear symptoms consistent with betanodavirus infection, also known as viral nervous necrosis (VNN). The discovery was made possible thanks to a report from a member of the Barcelona Underwater Fishing Association (APS), who sent the specimen to the Fish Pathology Diagnostic Service at the Universitat Autonoma de Barcelona (UAB). Samples of the fish were then sent to the European reference laboratory for this disease, where molecular techniques (qPCR) confirmed a very high presence of the virus in the animal's brain.

This identification, together with other reports of dead or symptomatic groupers, unequivocally confirms the spread of VNN and its presence in the coastal waters of Catalonia. For several years now, this betanodavirus has been causing outbreaks of mortality in groupers and other fish species throughout the Mediterranean, with particularly severe outbreaks in Greece, southern Italy, Spain, and recently in the Azores. In Spain, this virus had already caused outbreaks in the Balearic Islands, and a few years ago outbreaks were detected on the coast of the peninsula, with a progressive advance northwards causing very significant mortality of groupers in nature reserves such as Cabrera and Columbretes.

This year, the intercity bus routes connecting with the UAB will add almost 90 new departures. This affects the Barcelona-Cerdanyola-UAB, Sabadell-Barbera-Badia-UAB, Mataro-Argentona-UAB, Igualada-Martorell-UAB, and Montcada-Ripollet-UAB lines. These improvements are part of the Intercity Bus Emergency Plan, which receives an investment of EUR17 million. Bus a l'eix central de la UAB

On 19 September, UAB Rector Javier Lafuente was accompanied by Xavier Gabarrell, vice-rector for Campus and Sustainability, and Manel Nadal, secretary for Mobility and Infrastructure of the Government of Catalonia, at the presentation of the improvements for this 2025/26 academic year, which included almost 90 new departures of several intercity buses connecting the nearby towns with the UAB.

Source: Company Website

September 18: Autonomous University of Barcelona Horses, possible allies in forest fire prevention

The research-which included the participation of Boumort Wildland, the Miranda Foundation, the Forest Horses association, and the University of Barcelona (UB)-reveals that horses adapt their diet according to breed, environment and use. This flexibility helps them play a complementary role alongside other herbivores in sustainable fire prevention strategies, given that their grazing reduces fuel loads and maintains open landscapes. The study was co-authored by researchers from the Department of Animal and Food Science at the UAB Jordi Bartolome and Araceli Gort-Esteve.

"Until now research on extensive herding and forest fire prevention has focused mainly on sheep and goats, with some isolated studies done on breeds of rustic cattle. There have been very few studies on horses within this context, since traditionally they are classified as plant grazers that have little effect on woody vegetations", explains Ariadna Nieto-Espinet, Ramon y Cajal researcher at the UdL and zooarchaeologist. "Our work is one of the first to use empirical data to analyse their potential in forest management in the Mediterannean", she adds.

Source: Company Website

September 18: The UAB brings together leading experts in space communications in Barcelona

On 22 and 23 September, Casa Convalescencia UAB will host the Satellite Network of Experts V Seasonal School, with the participation of leading experts in satellite and space communications such as Holly Ridings from NASA and Oana Graur from ESA. Satellits

The Quantum Communication and Secure Information (Q-CSI) research group, from the Department of Telecommunications and Systems Engineering at the UAB, organises the EURASIP Satellite Network of Experts V Seasonal School, a project of the European Space Agency (ESA) within the framework of the Connectivity and Secure Communications (CSC) department, co-organised by the Institute of Space Studies of Catalonia (IEEC).

The school is aimed at early-stage researchers and industry professionals, PhD students, and postdoctoral researchers interested in exploring the latest advances in satellite and space communications. It will take place on 22 and 23 Septemeber at Casa Convalescencia UAB and is organised in conjunction with the International Conference on Satellite Systems Communications (ICSSC 2025) of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics (AIAA), which will take place from 23 to 25 September.

Source: Company Website

September 18: Sixty-four internships to explain the UAB to future UABers

If you are a UAB student and want to share your experience with others, this is your chance! We are looking for 64 undergraduate and graduate students interested in explaining the different degrees and services offered at the UAB and solve any doubts future UABers may have.

We offer three different internships, one with 60 places and two more with two places each:

The first is the Promotional activities which consists in 100 hours distributed throughout the months of January and May 2026, and focusing on student participation in activities and events, such as the Education Fair, Open Days, Family Days and other activities, both on-site and online. All of the activities can be found at the #VisitTheUAB website. Students will receive a grant of 746 euros gross in total. A total of 60 placements are offered to students from all faculties and schools, to be able to explain the wide range of academic programmes available at the UAB. You must sign up through Nexus.

urn:contentItem:6GVW-H2N3-RX09-9029-00000-00Updated: September 26, 2025: Autonomous University of Barcelona: FAS celebrates its 25th anniversary at La Comunitaria and other recent news2025-09-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:34:14ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSUpdated: September 26, 2025: Autonomous University of Barcelona: FAS celebrates its 25th anniversary at La Comunitaria and other recent news

Tuesday 30 September the UAB will be holding La Comunitaria and the Fundacio Autonoma Solidaria (FAS) will be there with a very special stand to celebrate 25 years of social actions at university. From 12 noon to 4:00 p.m. the Placa del Coneixement will be the site of activities, games and spaces to chat about the programmes and people who have helped to make changes, and also benefited from these social actions.
